html/lib/XS/APItest.html:57:<p>This module tests the perl C API. Currently tests that <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#printf"><code>printf</code></a>
html/lib/XS/APItest.html:76:correctly by <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#printf"><code>printf</code></a>.</p>
html/lib/XS/APItest.html:90:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#printf"><code>printf</code></a>. Takes no arguments - the test value is hard-wired
html/lib/XS/APItest.html:116:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#printf"><code>printf</code></a>.</p>
html/lib/XS/APItest.html:130:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#printf"><code>printf</code></a>.</p>
html/lib/XS/APItest.html:144:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#printf"><code>printf</code></a>.</p>
html/lib/XS/APItest.html:157:<p>Test that an <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#int"><code>int</code></a> is formatted correctly by
html/lib/XS/APItest.html:158:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#printf"><code>printf</code></a>.</p>
html/lib/XS/APItest.html:172:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#printf"><code>printf</code></a>.</p>
html/lib/XS/APItest.html:186:correctly by <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#printf"><code>printf</code></a>.</p>
html/lib/XS/APItest.html:235:<p><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/lib/XS/Typemap.html">the XS::Typemap manpage</a>, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlapi.html">the perlapi manpage</a>.</p>
html/lib/XSLoader.html:77:<p>For a more complicated interface, see <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/lib/DynaLoader.html">the DynaLoader manpage</a>.  Many (most)
html/lib/XSLoader.html:83:<p>A typical module using <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/lib/DynaLoader.html">DynaLoader</a> starts like this:</p>
html/lib/XSLoader.html:104:the <code>@ISA</code> assignment at all; moreover, if instead of <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#our"><code>our</code></a> one uses the
html/lib/XSLoader.html:133:<code>use XSLoader</code> by <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#require"><code>require</code></a>, so the compiler does not know that a function
html/lib/XSLoader.html:143:or have a <code>BOOT:</code> section in your XS file (see <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlxs.html#the_boot__keyword">The BOOT: Keyword in the perlxs manpage</a>).
html/lib/XSLoader.html:144:What is described here is equally applicable to the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/lib/DynaLoader.html">DynaLoader</a>
html/lib/XSLoader.html:252:delegated to <code>DynaLoader</code>, which looks for the DLL along the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#_inc"><code>@INC</code></a> list.</p>
html/lib/XSLoader.html:253:<p>In particular, this is applicable to the structure of <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#_inc"><code>@INC</code></a> used for testing
html/lib/XSLoader.html:266:<p><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/lib/DynaLoader.html">the DynaLoader manpage</a></p>

html/pod/perl5005delta.html:537:<p>The <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlop.html#qr_"><code>qr//</code></a> operator, which is syntactically similar to the other quote-like
html/pod/perl5005delta.html:540:other regular expressions.  See <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlop.html">the perlop manpage</a>.</p>
html/pod/perl5005delta.html:543:<h2><a name="our_is_now_a_reserved_word"><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#our"><code>our</code></a> is now a reserved word</a></h2>
html/pod/perl5005delta.html:544:<p>Calling a subroutine with the name <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#our"><code>our</code></a> will now provoke a warning when
html/pod/perl5005delta.html:545:using the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#w"><code>-w</code></a> switch.</p>
html/pod/perl5005delta.html:549:<p>See <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/lib/Tie/Array.html">the Tie::Array manpage</a>.</p>
html/pod/perl5005delta.html:554:TIEARRAY implementations.  See <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/lib/Tie/Array.html">the Tie::Array manpage</a>.</p>
html/pod/perl5005delta.html:558:<p><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#substr"><code>substr()</code></a> can now both return and replace in one operation.  The optional
html/pod/perl5005delta.html:559:4th argument is the replacement string.  See <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#substr">substr in the perlfunc manpage</a>.</p>
html/pod/perl5005delta.html:563:<p><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#splice"><code>splice()</code></a> with a negative LENGTH argument now work similar to what the
html/pod/perl5005delta.html:564:LENGTH did for <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#substr"><code>substr()</code></a>.  Previously a negative LENGTH was treated as
html/pod/perl5005delta.html:565:0.  See <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#splice">splice in the perlfunc manpage</a>.</p>
html/pod/perl5005delta.html:569:<p>When you say something like <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#substr"><code>substr($x, 5) = &quot;hi&quot;</code></a>, the scalar returned
html/pod/perl5005delta.html:570:by <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#substr"><code>substr()</code></a> is special, in that any modifications to it affect $x.
html/pod/perl5005delta.html:573:would expect to happen, but Perl uses the same magic if you use <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#substr"><code>substr()</code></a>,
html/pod/perl5005delta.html:574:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#pos"><code>pos()</code></a>, or <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#vec"><code>vec()</code></a> in a context where they might be modified, like taking
html/pod/perl5005delta.html:575:a reference with <code>\</code> or as an argument to a sub that modifies <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>@_</code></a>.
html/pod/perl5005delta.html:590:<p>If <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>$/</code></a> is a reference to an integer, or a scalar that holds an integer,
html/pod/perl5005delta.html:592:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#_e_sol_">$&sol; in the perlvar manpage</a>.</p>
html/pod/perl5005delta.html:605:as <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perldos.html">the perldos manpage</a> on some systems).</p>
html/pod/perl5005delta.html:609:(installed as <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlos390.html">the perlos390 manpage</a> on some systems).</p>
html/pod/perl5005delta.html:616:See <em class="file">README.win32</em>, aka <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlwin32.html">the perlwin32 manpage</a>.</p>
html/pod/perl5005delta.html:631:<p>Perl compiler and tools.  See <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/lib/B.html">the B manpage</a>.</p>

html/pod/perl5100delta.html:396:<h2><a name="lexical___">Lexical <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>$_</code></a></a></h2>
html/pod/perl5100delta.html:397:<p>The default variable <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>$_</code></a> can now be lexicalized, by declaring it like
html/pod/perl5100delta.html:401:<p>The operations that default on <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>$_</code></a> will use the lexically-scoped
html/pod/perl5100delta.html:402:version of <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>$_</code></a> when it exists, instead of the global <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>$_</code></a>.</p>
html/pod/perl5100delta.html:403:<p>In a <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#map"><code>map</code></a> or a <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#grep"><code>grep</code></a> block, if <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>$_</code></a> was previously my'ed, then the
html/pod/perl5100delta.html:404:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>$_</code></a> inside the block is lexical as well (and scoped to the block).</p>
html/pod/perl5100delta.html:405:<p>In a scope where <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>$_</code></a> has been lexicalized, you can still have access to
html/pod/perl5100delta.html:406:the global version of <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>$_</code></a> by using <code>$::_</code>, or, more simply, by
html/pod/perl5100delta.html:407:overriding the lexical declaration with <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#our"><code>our $_</code></a>. (Rafael Garcia-Suarez)</p>
html/pod/perl5100delta.html:412:defaults to <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>$_</code></a> if the corresponding argument isn't supplied. (both <code>$</code>
html/pod/perl5100delta.html:415:<p>This has a small incompatible consequence: the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#prototype"><code>prototype()</code></a> function has
html/pod/perl5100delta.html:417:example, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#prototype"><code>prototype('CORE::rmdir')</code></a>). (Rafael Garcia-Suarez)</p>
html/pod/perl5100delta.html:427:just after the unit which defined them has been compiled. See <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlmod.html">the perlmod manpage</a>

html/pod/perl561delta.html:1237:<h2><a name="improved_qw___operator">Improved <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlop.html#qw_"><code>qw//</code></a> operator</a></h2>

html/pod/perl561delta.html:1239:instead of being replaced with a run time call to <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#split"><code>split()</code></a>.  This

html/pod/perl561delta.html:1241:had inherited that behaviour from <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#split"><code>split()</code></a>.</p>

html/pod/perl561delta.html:2698:<h2><a name="eval_______improvements"><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#eval"><code>eval '...'</code></a> improvements</a></h2>
html/pod/perl561delta.html:2700:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#eval"><code>eval '...'</code></a> were often incorrect where here documents were involved.
html/pod/perl561delta.html:2702:<p>Lexical lookups for variables appearing in <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#eval"><code>eval '...'</code></a> within
html/pod/perl561delta.html:2703:functions that were themselves called within an <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#eval"><code>eval '...'</code></a> were
html/pod/perl561delta.html:2706:<p>The use of <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#return"><code>return</code></a> within <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#eval"><code>eval {...}</code></a> caused $@ not to be reset
html/pod/perl561delta.html:2724:when code was compiled at run time using <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#eval"><code>eval STRING</code></a>, and
html/pod/perl561delta.html:2725:also allows such errors to be reliably trapped using <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#eval"><code>eval &quot;...&quot;</code></a>.</p>
html/pod/perl561delta.html:2752:<p>See <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perldata.html">the perldata manpage</a>.</p>
html/pod/perl561delta.html:2761:<p>The <code>goto &amp;sub</code> construct works correctly when <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#sub"><code>&amp;sub</code></a> happens
html/pod/perl561delta.html:2780:<p><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#printf"><code>printf()</code></a> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#sprintf"><code>sprintf()</code></a> previously reset the numeric locale
html/pod/perl561delta.html:2794:<p>Constructs that modified <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>@_</code></a> could fail to deallocate values
html/pod/perl561delta.html:2795:in <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>@_</code></a> and thus leak memory.  This has been corrected.</p>

html/pod/perl56delta.html:554:<h2><a name="improved_qw___operator">Improved <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlop.html#qw_"><code>qw//</code></a> operator</a></h2>
html/pod/perl56delta.html:555:<p>The <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlop.html#qw_"><code>qw//</code></a> operator is now evaluated at compile time into a true list
html/pod/perl56delta.html:556:instead of being replaced with a run time call to <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#split"><code>split()</code></a>.  This
html/pod/perl56delta.html:557:removes the confusing misbehaviour of <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlop.html#qw_"><code>qw//</code></a> in scalar context, which
html/pod/perl56delta.html:558:had inherited that behaviour from <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#split"><code>split()</code></a>.</p>

html/pod/perl56delta.html:729:<p>On Unix and similar platforms, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#system"><code>system()</code></a>, <code>qx()</code> and open(FOO, &quot;cmd |&quot;)
html/pod/perl56delta.html:730:etc., are implemented via <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#fork"><code>fork()</code></a> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#exec"><code>exec()</code></a>.  When the underlying
html/pod/perl56delta.html:731:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#exec"><code>exec()</code></a> fails, earlier versions did not report the error properly,
html/pod/perl56delta.html:732:since the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#exec"><code>exec()</code></a> happened to be in a different process.</p>
html/pod/perl56delta.html:746:if <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#sort"><code>sort()</code></a> is encountered in package <code>foo</code>.</p>
html/pod/perl56delta.html:760:    Not enough arguments for scalar at (eval 4)[newlib/<a href="<a href="file://C">file://C</a>|\camelbox\html/lib/perl5db:">perl5db</a>.pl:1411] line 2, at EOF</pre>

html/pod/perl56delta.html:772:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#socket"><code>socket()</code></a>, and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#accept"><code>accept()</code></a>, if that is warranted by the value of $^F

html/pod/perl56delta.html:780:<p>The length argument of <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#syswrite"><code>syswrite()</code></a> has become optional.</p>

html/pod/perl56delta.html:816:<p>The <code>passwd</code> and <code>shell</code> fields returned by the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#getpwent"><code>getpwent()</code></a>, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#getpwnam"><code>getpwnam()</code></a>,

html/pod/perl56delta.html:2008:<h2><a name="eval_______improvements"><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#eval"><code>eval '...'</code></a> improvements</a></h2>
html/pod/perl56delta.html:2009:<p>Line numbers (as reflected by <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#caller"><code>caller()</code></a> and most diagnostics) within
html/pod/perl56delta.html:2010:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#eval"><code>eval '...'</code></a> were often incorrect where here documents were involved.
html/pod/perl56delta.html:2012:<p>Lexical lookups for variables appearing in <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#eval"><code>eval '...'</code></a> within
html/pod/perl56delta.html:2013:functions that were themselves called within an <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#eval"><code>eval '...'</code></a> were
html/pod/perl56delta.html:2016:<p>The use of <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#return"><code>return</code></a> within <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#eval"><code>eval {...}</code></a> caused $@ not to be reset
html/pod/perl56delta.html:2034:when code was compiled at run time using <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#eval"><code>eval STRING</code></a>, and
html/pod/perl56delta.html:2035:also allows such errors to be reliably trapped using <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#eval"><code>eval &quot;...&quot;</code></a>.</p>
html/pod/perl56delta.html:2062:<p>See <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perldata.html">the perldata manpage</a>.</p>
html/pod/perl56delta.html:2071:<p>The <code>goto &amp;sub</code> construct works correctly when <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#sub"><code>&amp;sub</code></a> happens
html/pod/perl56delta.html:2090:<p><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#printf"><code>printf()</code></a> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#sprintf"><code>sprintf()</code></a> previously reset the numeric locale
html/pod/perl56delta.html:2104:<p>Constructs that modified <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>@_</code></a> could fail to deallocate values
html/pod/perl56delta.html:2105:in <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>@_</code></a> and thus leak memory.  This has been corrected.</p>

html/pod/perl56delta.html:2223:as in the first argument to <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#join"><code>join</code></a>.  Perl will treat the true
html/pod/perl56delta.html:2237:an ampersand before the name to avoid the warning.  See <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlsub.html">the perlsub manpage</a>.</p>

html/pod/perl56delta.html:2273:<p>(F) The argument to <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#exists"><code>exists()</code></a> for <code>exists &amp;sub</code> must be a subroutine
html/pod/perl56delta.html:2274:name, and not a subroutine call.  <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#sub"><code>exists &amp;sub()</code></a> will generate this error.</p>

html/pod/perl58delta.html:649:<p>The builtin <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#dump"><code>dump()</code></a> now gives an optional warning

html/pod/perl58delta.html:651:meaning that by default <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#dump"><code>dump(...)</code></a> is resolved as the builtin
html/pod/perl58delta.html:652:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#dump"><code>dump()</code></a> which dumps core and aborts, not as (possibly) user-defined
html/pod/perl58delta.html:653:<code>sub dump</code>.  To call the latter, qualify the call as <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#dump"><code>&amp;dump(...)</code></a>.

html/pod/perl593delta.html:157:<p><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#mkdir"><code>mkdir()</code></a> without arguments now defaults to <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>$_</code></a>.</p>
html/pod/perl593delta.html:161:<p>The construct <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#eval"><code>eval { goto &amp;foo }</code></a> is now disallowed. (Note that the

html/pod/perl595delta.html:363:<h2><a name="readpipe___is_now_overridable"><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#readpipe"><code>readpipe()</code></a> is now overridable</a></h2>
html/pod/perl595delta.html:364:<p>The built-in function <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#readpipe"><code>readpipe()</code></a> is now overridable. Overriding it permits
html/pod/perl595delta.html:365:also to override its operator counterpart, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlop.html#qx_"><code>qx//</code></a> (a.k.a. <code>``</code>).
html/pod/perl595delta.html:366:Moreover, it now defaults to <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>$_</code></a> if no argument is provided. (Rafael)</p>

html/pod/perldelta.html:390:<h2><a name="say__"><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#say"><code>say()</code></a></a></h2>
html/pod/perldelta.html:391:<p><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#say"><code>say()</code></a> is a new built-in, only available when <code>use feature 'say'</code> is in
html/pod/perldelta.html:392:effect, that is similar to <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#print"><code>print()</code></a>, but that implicitly appends a newline
html/pod/perldelta.html:393:to the printed string. See <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#say">say in the perlfunc manpage</a>. (Robin Houston)</p>
html/pod/perldelta.html:396:<h2><a name="lexical___">Lexical <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>$_</code></a></a></h2>
html/pod/perldelta.html:397:<p>The default variable <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>$_</code></a> can now be lexicalized, by declaring it like
html/pod/perldelta.html:401:<p>The operations that default on <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>$_</code></a> will use the lexically-scoped
html/pod/perldelta.html:402:version of <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>$_</code></a> when it exists, instead of the global <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>$_</code></a>.</p>
html/pod/perldelta.html:403:<p>In a <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#map"><code>map</code></a> or a <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#grep"><code>grep</code></a> block, if <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>$_</code></a> was previously my'ed, then the
html/pod/perldelta.html:404:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>$_</code></a> inside the block is lexical as well (and scoped to the block).</p>
html/pod/perldelta.html:405:<p>In a scope where <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>$_</code></a> has been lexicalized, you can still have access to
html/pod/perldelta.html:406:the global version of <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>$_</code></a> by using <code>$::_</code>, or, more simply, by
html/pod/perldelta.html:407:overriding the lexical declaration with <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#our"><code>our $_</code></a>. (Rafael Garcia-Suarez)</p>
html/pod/perldelta.html:412:defaults to <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>$_</code></a> if the corresponding argument isn't supplied. (both <code>$</code>
html/pod/perldelta.html:415:<p>This has a small incompatible consequence: the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#prototype"><code>prototype()</code></a> function has
html/pod/perldelta.html:417:example, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#prototype"><code>prototype('CORE::rmdir')</code></a>). (Rafael Garcia-Suarez)</p>
html/pod/perldelta.html:427:just after the unit which defined them has been compiled. See <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlmod.html">the perlmod manpage</a>
html/pod/perldelta.html:436:available: the C3 algorithm. See <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/lib/mro.html">the mro manpage</a> for more information.
html/pod/perldelta.html:450:Cwd::cwd() may return a short directory name, and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#glob"><code>glob()</code></a> may return short
html/pod/perldelta.html:464:UTF-8 encoded arguments.  Please see <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/lib/Win32.html">the Win32 manpage</a> for details.</p>
html/pod/perldelta.html:467:<h2><a name="readpipe___is_now_overridable"><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#readpipe"><code>readpipe()</code></a> is now overridable</a></h2>
html/pod/perldelta.html:468:<p>The built-in function <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#readpipe"><code>readpipe()</code></a> is now overridable. Overriding it permits
html/pod/perldelta.html:469:also to override its operator counterpart, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlop.html#qx_"><code>qx//</code></a> (a.k.a. <code>``</code>).
html/pod/perldelta.html:470:Moreover, it now defaults to <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>$_</code></a> if no argument is provided. (Rafael
html/pod/perldelta.html:474:<h2><a name="default_argument_for_readline__">Default argument for <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#readline"><code>readline()</code></a></a></h2>
html/pod/perldelta.html:475:<p><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#readline"><code>readline()</code></a> now defaults to <code>*ARGV</code> if no argument is provided. (Rafael
html/pod/perldelta.html:479:<h2><a name="state___variables"><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#state"><code>state()</code></a> variables</a></h2>

html/pod/perldsc.html:285:<p>That's because <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#my"><code>my()</code></a> is more of a run-time statement than it is a
html/pod/perldsc.html:286:compile-time declaration <em>per se</em>.  This means that the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#my"><code>my()</code></a> variable is
html/pod/perldsc.html:318:element of <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#a"><code>a</code></a>.  That is, they first take the subscript, and only then
html/pod/perldsc.html:336:<p>This way, you'll be forced to declare all your variables with <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#my"><code>my()</code></a> and
html/pod/perldsc.html:359:well as the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#x"><code>x</code></a> command to dump out complex data structures.  For
html/pod/perldsc.html:896:module.  Check your nearest CPAN site as described in <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlmodlib.html">the perlmodlib manpage</a> for

html/pod/perlfaq.html:897:<h2><a name="perlfaq8__system_interaction"><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfaq8.html">the perlfaq8 manpage</a>: System Interaction</a></h2>
html/pod/perlfaq.html:898:<p>This section of the Perl FAQ covers questions involving operating system interaction. Topics include interprocess communication (IPC), control over the user-interface (keyboard, screen and pointing devices), and most anything else not related to data manipulation. Read the FAQs and documentation specific to the port of perl to your operating system (eg, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvms.html">the perlvms manpage</a>, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlplan9.html">the perlplan9 manpage</a>, ...). These should contain more detailed information on the vagaries of your perl.</p>

html/pod/perlfaq3.html:184:<p>Beyond that, the simplest debugger is the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#print"><code>print</code></a> function. Use it

html/pod/perlfaq3.html:246:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlstyle.html">the perlstyle manpage</a>. If you write Perl scripts, or spend much time reading
html/pod/perlfaq3.html:249:<p>Of course, if you simply follow the guidelines in <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlstyle.html">the perlstyle manpage</a>,
html/pod/perlfaq3.html:693:<p>In some cases, using <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#substr"><code>substr()</code></a> or <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#vec"><code>vec()</code></a> to simulate arrays can be
html/pod/perlfaq3.html:812:<p>You usually can't. Memory allocated to lexicals (i.e. <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#my"><code>my()</code></a> variables)
html/pod/perlfaq3.html:816:undef()ing and/or <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#delete"><code>delete()</code></a>.</p>

html/pod/perlfaq3.html:920:<p>as the first line in <code>*.cmd</code> file (<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#s"><code>-S</code></a> due to a bug in cmd.exe's

html/pod/perlfaq3.html:1026:<p>If you want to call C from Perl, start with <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlxstut.html">the perlxstut manpage</a>,
html/pod/perlfaq3.html:1027:moving on to <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlxs.html">the perlxs manpage</a>, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/lib/ExtUtils/xsubpp.html">the xsubpp manpage</a>, and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html">the perlguts manpage</a>.  If you want to

html/pod/perlfaq3.html:1042:fail, see <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/utils/perlbug.html">the perlbug manpage</a> and send a bug report with the output of

html/pod/perlfaq4.html:172:<h2><a name="why_is_int___broken">Why is <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#int"><code>int()</code></a> broken?</a></h2>
html/pod/perlfaq4.html:173:<p>Your <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#int"><code>int()</code></a> is most probably working just fine.  It's the numbers that
html/pod/perlfaq4.html:192:conversion takes place.  You must explicitly use <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#oct"><code>oct()</code></a> or <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#hex"><code>hex()</code></a> if you
html/pod/perlfaq4.html:193:want the values converted to decimal.  <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#oct"><code>oct()</code></a> interprets hexadecimal (<code>0x350</code>),
html/pod/perlfaq4.html:195:(<code>0b1010</code>) numbers, while <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#hex"><code>hex()</code></a> only converts hexadecimal ones, with
html/pod/perlfaq4.html:198:&lt;%o&gt; or <code>%O</code> <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#sprintf"><code>sprintf()</code></a> formats.</p>
html/pod/perlfaq4.html:199:<p>This problem shows up most often when people try using <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#chmod"><code>chmod()</code></a>,
html/pod/perlfaq4.html:200:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#mkdir"><code>mkdir()</code></a>, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#umask"><code>umask()</code></a>, or <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#sysopen"><code>sysopen()</code></a>, which by widespread tradition
html/pod/perlfaq4.html:210:<p>Surely you had not intended <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#chmod"><code>chmod(01204, $file);</code></a> - did you?  If you
html/pod/perlfaq4.html:211:want to use numeric literals as arguments to <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#chmod"><code>chmod()</code></a> et al. then please
html/pod/perlfaq4.html:217:<p>Remember that <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#int"><code>int()</code></a> merely truncates toward 0.  For rounding to a
html/pod/perlfaq4.html:218:certain number of digits, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#sprintf"><code>sprintf()</code></a> or <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#printf"><code>printf()</code></a> is usually the
html/pod/perlfaq4.html:258:<p>Some of the examples later in <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfaq4.html">the perlfaq4 manpage</a> use the <code>Bit::Vector</code>
html/pod/perlfaq4.html:274:<p>Using the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#hex"><code>hex</code></a> function:</p>
html/pod/perlfaq4.html:281:<p>Using <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#pack"><code>pack</code></a>:</p>
html/pod/perlfaq4.html:300:<p>Using <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#sprintf"><code>sprintf</code></a>:</p>

html/pod/perlfaq4.html:406:<p>Using <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#pack"><code>pack</code></a> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#unpack"><code>unpack</code></a> for larger strings:</p>

html/pod/perlfaq4.html:528:<p>If you're using a version of Perl before 5.004, you must call <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#srand"><code>srand</code></a>
html/pod/perlfaq4.html:532:<p>5.004 and later automatically call <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#srand"><code>srand</code></a> at the beginning.  Don't
html/pod/perlfaq4.html:533:call <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#srand"><code>srand</code></a> more than once--you make your numbers less random,
html/pod/perlfaq4.html:542:<p>If you want numbers that are more random than <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#rand"><code>rand</code></a> with <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#srand"><code>srand</code></a>
html/pod/perlfaq4.html:551:<p>To get a random number between two values, you can use the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#rand"><code>rand()</code></a>
html/pod/perlfaq4.html:554:<p><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#rand"><code>rand($x)</code></a> returns a number such that <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#rand"><code>0 &lt;= rand($x) &lt; $x</code></a>. Thus
html/pod/perlfaq4.html:696:<p>When <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#gmtime"><code>gmtime()</code></a> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#localtime"><code>localtime()</code></a> are used in scalar context they return

html/pod/perlfaq4.html:728:<p>This won't expand <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#n"><code>&quot;\n&quot;</code></a> or <a href="#t"><code>&quot;\t&quot;</code></a> or any other special escapes.</p>
html/pod/perlfaq4.html:741:<p>We can also use the transliteration operator, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlop.html#tr_"><code>tr///</code></a>. In this

html/pod/perlfaq4.html:864:<p>You can access the first characters of a string with <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#substr"><code>substr()</code></a>.
html/pod/perlfaq4.html:874:<p>You can also use <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#substr"><code>substr()</code></a> as an lvalue.</p>

html/pod/perlfaq4.html:1055:<p>The simplest method uses the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#sprintf"><code>sprintf</code></a> function. It can pad on the left

html/pod/perlfaq4.html:1092:use <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#substr"><code>substr</code></a> to extract a single column.</p>

html/pod/perlfaq4.html:1865:<h2><a name="why_does_defined___return_true_on_empty_arrays_and_hashes">Why does <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#defined"><code>defined()</code></a> return true on empty arrays and hashes?</a></h2>
html/pod/perlfaq4.html:1867:functions, not on aggregates (arrays and hashes).  See <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#defined">defined in the perlfunc manpage</a>
html/pod/perlfaq4.html:1880:<p>To go through all of the keys, use the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#keys"><code>keys</code></a> function. This extracts
html/pod/perlfaq4.html:1898:those using <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#grep"><code>grep</code></a>:</p>
html/pod/perlfaq4.html:1906:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#each"><code>each()</code></a>, which returns a pair you haven't seen yet:</p>
html/pod/perlfaq4.html:1911:<p>The <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#each"><code>each</code></a> operator returns the pairs in apparently random order, so if
html/pod/perlfaq4.html:1912:ordering matters to you, you'll have to stick with the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#keys"><code>keys</code></a> method.</p>
html/pod/perlfaq4.html:1913:<p>The <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#each"><code>each()</code></a> operator can be a bit tricky though. You can't add or
html/pod/perlfaq4.html:1917:you use <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#keys"><code>keys</code></a>, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#values"><code>values</code></a>, or <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#each"><code>each</code></a> on the same hash, you can reset
html/pod/perlfaq4.html:1918:the iterator and mess up your processing. See the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#each"><code>each</code></a> entry in
html/pod/perlfaq4.html:1919:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html">the perlfunc manpage</a> for more details.</p>
html/pod/perlfaq4.html:1925:<p>If you iterate through the hash with <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#each"><code>each()</code></a>, you can delete the key
html/pod/perlfaq4.html:1929:entry for <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#each"><code>each()</code></a> in <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html">the perlfunc manpage</a>.</p>
html/pod/perlfaq4.html:1954:use the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#keys"><code>keys()</code></a> function in a scalar context:</p>
html/pod/perlfaq4.html:1957:<p>The <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#keys"><code>keys()</code></a> function also resets the iterator, which means that you may
html/pod/perlfaq4.html:1959:such as <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#each"><code>each()</code></a>.</p>

html/pod/perlfaq4.html:2091:<p>You can use the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#keys"><code>keys</code></a> or <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#values"><code>values</code></a> functions to reset <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#each"><code>each</code></a>. html/pod/perlfaq5.html:725:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#flock"><code>flock(2)</code></a> if that exists, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#fcntl"><code>fcntl(2)</code></a> if it doesn't (on perl version 5.004 and
html/pod/perlfaq5.html:739:<p>Some versions of <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#flock"><code>flock()</code></a> can't lock files over a network (e.g. on NFS file
html/pod/perlfaq5.html:740:systems), so you'd need to force the use of <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#fcntl"><code>fcntl(2)</code></a> when you build Perl.
html/pod/perlfaq5.html:741:But even this is dubious at best.  See the flock entry of <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html">the perlfunc manpage</a>
html/pod/perlfaq5.html:747:offer fewer guarantees.  This means that files locked with <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#flock"><code>flock()</code></a> may
html/pod/perlfaq5.html:748:be modified by programs that do not also use <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#flock"><code>flock()</code></a>.  Cars that stop
html/pod/perlfaq5.html:758:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlopentut.html#file_locking">File Locking in the perlopentut manpage</a> if you have it (new for 5.6).</p>
html/pod/perlfaq5.html:776:Various schemes involving <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#link"><code>link()</code></a> have been suggested, but
html/pod/perlfaq5.html:802:<p>If you are on a system that correctly implements <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#flock"><code>flock()</code></a> and you use the

html/pod/perlfaq5.html:820:the system level <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#write"><code>write()</code></a> operation before completion.  There is also a

html/pod/perlfaq5.html:964:<p>You can use the builtin <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#getc"><code>getc()</code></a> function for most filehandles, but

html/pod/perlfaq6.html:384:<h2><a name="what_is__o_really_for">What is <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#o"><code>/o</code></a> really for?</a></h2>
html/pod/perlfaq6.html:386:<p>The <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#o"><code>/o</code></a> option for regular expressions (documented in <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlop.html">the perlop manpage</a> and
html/pod/perlfaq6.html:387:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlreref.html">the perlreref manpage</a>) tells Perl to compile the regular expression only once.
html/pod/perlfaq6.html:390:<p>Since the match operator <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlop.html#m_"><code>m//</code></a>, the substitution operator <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlop.html#s_"><code>s///</code></a>,
html/pod/perlfaq6.html:391:and the regular expression quoting operator <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlop.html#qr_"><code>qr//</code></a> are double-quotish
html/pod/perlfaq6.html:404:for each iteration, even if <code>$pattern</code> had not changed. The <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#o"><code>/o</code></a>
html/pod/perlfaq6.html:414:if the variable hasn't changed, so you probably don't need the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#o"><code>/o</code></a>
html/pod/perlfaq6.html:418:need the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#o"><code>/o</code></a>.</p>
html/pod/perlfaq6.html:450:<p>This could, of course, be more legibly written with the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#x"><code>/x</code></a> modifier, adding

html/pod/perlfaq7.html:620:<h2><a name="what_s_the_difference_between_dynamic_and_lexical__static__scoping_between_local___and_my__">What's the difference between dynamic and lexical (static) scoping?  Between <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#local"><code>local()</code></a> and my()?</a></h2>
html/pod/perlfaq7.html:621:<p><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#local"><code>local($x)</code></a> saves away the old value of the global variable <code>$x</code>
html/pod/perlfaq7.html:624:at run-time, so is called dynamic scoping.  <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#local"><code>local()</code></a> always affects global
html/pod/perlfaq7.html:626:<p><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#my"><code>my($x)</code></a> creates a new variable that is only visible in the current
html/pod/perlfaq7.html:628:static scoping.  <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#my"><code>my()</code></a> always affects private variables, also called
html/pod/perlfaq7.html:654:<p>In summary, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#local"><code>local()</code></a> doesn't make what you think of as private, local
html/pod/perlfaq7.html:655:variables.  It gives a global variable a temporary value.  <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#my"><code>my()</code></a> is
html/pod/perlfaq7.html:657:<p>See <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlsub.html#private_variables_via_my__">Private Variables via my() in the perlsub manpage</a> and
html/pod/perlfaq7.html:658:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlsub.html#temporary_values_via_local__">Temporary Values via local() in the perlsub manpage</a> for excruciating details.</p>
html/pod/perlfaq7.html:673:<p>Alternatively you can use the compiler directive <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#our"><code>our()</code></a> to bring a
html/pod/perlfaq7.html:702:<p><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#my"><code>my()</code></a> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#local"><code>local()</code></a> give list context to the right hand side
html/pod/perlfaq7.html:705:behaves appropriately.  In general, the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#scalar"><code>scalar()</code></a> function can help.

html/pod/perlfaq8.html:693:<p>With <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#system"><code>system()</code></a>, both STDOUT and STDERR will go the same place as the
html/pod/perlfaq8.html:694:script's STDOUT and STDERR, unless the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#system"><code>system()</code></a> command redirects them.
html/pod/perlfaq8.html:695:Backticks and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#open"><code>open()</code></a> read <strong>only</strong> the STDOUT of your command.</p>
html/pod/perlfaq8.html:770:<p>This fails because the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#open"><code>open()</code></a> makes STDERR go to where STDOUT was
html/pod/perlfaq8.html:771:going at the time of the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#open"><code>open()</code></a>.  The backticks then make STDOUT go to

html/pod/perlfork.html:48:<p>perlfork - Perl's <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#fork"><code>fork()</code></a> emulation</p>
html/pod/perlfork.html:58:<p>Perl provides a <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#fork"><code>fork()</code></a> keyword that corresponds to the Unix system call
html/pod/perlfork.html:59:of the same name.  On most Unix-like platforms where the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#fork"><code>fork()</code></a> system
html/pod/perlfork.html:60:call is available, Perl's <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#fork"><code>fork()</code></a> simply calls it.</p>
html/pod/perlfork.html:61:<p>On some platforms such as Windows where the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#fork"><code>fork()</code></a> system call is not
html/pod/perlfork.html:62:available, Perl can be built to emulate <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#fork"><code>fork()</code></a> at the interpreter level.
html/pod/perlfork.html:64:real <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#fork"><code>fork()</code></a> at the level of the Perl program, there are certain
html/pod/perlfork.html:69:limitations of the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#fork"><code>fork()</code></a> emulation.  Note that the issues discussed here
html/pod/perlfork.html:70:are not applicable to platforms where a real <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#fork"><code>fork()</code></a> is available and Perl
html/pod/perlfork.html:76:<p>The <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#fork"><code>fork()</code></a> emulation is implemented at the level of the Perl interpreter.
html/pod/perlfork.html:77:What this means in general is that running <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#fork"><code>fork()</code></a> will actually clone the
html/pod/perlfork.html:80:point where the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#fork"><code>fork()</code></a> was called in the parent.  We will refer to the
html/pod/perlfork.html:82:<p>To the Perl program that called <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#fork"><code>fork()</code></a>, all this is designed to be
html/pod/perlfork.html:83:transparent.  The parent returns from the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#fork"><code>fork()</code></a> with a pseudo-process
html/pod/perlfork.html:85:the child returns from the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#fork"><code>fork()</code></a> with a value of <code>0</code> to signify that
html/pod/perlfork.html:120:<dt><strong><a name="wait" class="item"><code>wait()</code> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#waitpid"><code>waitpid()</code></a></a></strong>
html/pod/perlfork.html:123:<p><a href="#wait"><code>wait()</code></a> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#waitpid"><code>waitpid()</code></a> can be passed a pseudo-process ID returned by <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#fork"><code>fork()</code></a>.
html/pod/perlfork.html:132:by <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#fork"><code>fork()</code></a>.  This should not be used except under dire circumstances, because
html/pod/perlfork.html:146:what the earlier Perl <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#fork"><code>fork()</code></a> might have returned.  Similarly, any process

html/pod/perlfork.html:177:<p>In the eyes of the operating system, pseudo-processes created via the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#fork"><code>fork()</code></a>
html/pod/perlfork.html:208:<p>The <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#fork"><code>fork()</code></a> emulation will not work entirely correctly when called from
html/pod/perlfork.html:245:<p>Any filehandles open at the time of the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#fork"><code>fork()</code></a> will be dup()-ed.  Thus,
html/pod/perlfork.html:345:naturally when <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#fork"><code>fork()</code></a> is called.  A callback mechanism that provides
html/pod/perlfork.html:353:<p>The <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#fork"><code>fork()</code></a> emulation may not behave as expected when it is executed in an

html/pod/perlfork.html:379:<code>-1</code> because the <a href="#wait"><code>wait()</code></a> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#waitpid"><code>waitpid()</code></a> functions treat this number as

html/pod/perlhack.html:1073:<p>Perl's exception handing (i.e. <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#die"><code>die</code></a> etc.) is built on top of the low-level
html/pod/perlhack.html:1083:<code>JMPENV_JUMP</code>. The basic rule of perl exceptions is that <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#exit"><code>exit</code></a>, and

html/pod/perlhack.html:1093:occurs during an <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#exit"><code>exit</code></a>.</p>

html/pod/perlhack.html:1510:the stack: the <code>$x</code> in <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#cos"><code>cos($x)</code></a>. Then we compute the cosine, and push
html/pod/perlhack.html:1511:the result back as an NV. The <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#x"><code>X</code></a> in <code>XPUSHn</code> means that the stack

html/pod/perlhack.html:1665:<p>Most of these macros are explained in <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlapi.html">the perlapi manpage</a>, and some of the more

html/pod/perllexwarn.html:111:<h2><a name="what_s_wrong_with__w_and___w">What's wrong with <strong>-w</strong> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__w"><code>$^W</code></a></a></h2>
html/pod/perllexwarn.html:118:<p>Similarly, using <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__w"><code>$^W</code></a> to either disable or enable blocks of code is
html/pod/perllexwarn.html:128:for the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#_a"><code>$a</code></a> line -- <code>&quot;Reversed += operator&quot;</code>.</p>
html/pod/perllexwarn.html:137:<p>The other big problem with <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__w"><code>$^W</code></a> is the way you can inadvertently
html/pod/perllexwarn.html:154:<p>This is a side-effect of <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__w"><code>$^W</code></a> being dynamically scoped.</p>
html/pod/perllexwarn.html:177:locally using <code>no warnings</code> or <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__w"><code>$^W =0</code></a>. This includes all files that get
html/pod/perllexwarn.html:178:included via <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#use"><code>use</code></a>, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#require"><code>require</code></a> or <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#do"><code>do</code></a>.
html/pod/perllexwarn.html:194:lexical warnings and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__w"><code>$^W</code></a>, this section will describe how they interact.</p>
html/pod/perllexwarn.html:195:<p>How Lexical Warnings interact with <strong>-w</strong>/<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__w"><code>$^W</code></a>:</p>
html/pod/perllexwarn.html:199:control warnings is used and neither <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__w"><code>$^W</code></a> or the <code>warnings</code> pragma
html/pod/perllexwarn.html:206:<p>The <strong>-w</strong> flag just sets the global <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__w"><code>$^W</code></a> variable as in 5.005 -- this
html/pod/perllexwarn.html:207:means that any legacy code that currently relies on manipulating <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__w"><code>$^W</code></a>
html/pod/perllexwarn.html:211:<p>Apart from now being a boolean, the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__w"><code>$^W</code></a> variable operates in exactly
html/pod/perllexwarn.html:217:both the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__w"><code>$^W</code></a> variable and the <strong>-w</strong> flag will be ignored for the
html/pod/perllexwarn.html:339:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perldiag.html">the perldiag manpage</a>.</p>
html/pod/perllexwarn.html:348:into fatal errors. In the code below, the use of <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#time"><code>time</code></a>, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#length"><code>length</code></a>

html/pod/perlmint.html:190:pass a command line to <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#system"><code>system()</code></a> that exploits all features of a
html/pod/perlmint.html:191:POSIX shell.  If you use the MiNTLib version of <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#system"><code>system()</code></a> with
html/pod/perlmint.html:192:perl the Perl function <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#system"><code>system()</code></a> will suffer from the same deficiencies.</p>

html/pod/perlmod.html:290:executed inside string <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#eval"><code>eval()</code></a>'s.  The <code>CHECK</code> and <code>INIT</code> code

html/pod/perlmod.html:296:(But not if it's morphing into another program via <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#exec"><code>exec</code></a>, or
html/pod/perlmod.html:301:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#c"><code>-c</code></a> switch, or if compilation fails.</p>
html/pod/perlmod.html:303:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#eval"><code>eval()</code></a>: if any <code>END</code> code blocks are created in a string <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#eval"><code>eval()</code></a>,
html/pod/perlmod.html:306:<p>Inside an <code>END</code> code block, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#_"><code>$?</code></a> contains the value that the program is
html/pod/perlmod.html:307:going to pass to <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#exit"><code>exit()</code></a>.  You can modify <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#_"><code>$?</code></a> to change the exit
html/pod/perlmod.html:308:value of the program.  Beware of changing <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#_"><code>$?</code></a> by accident (e.g. by
html/pod/perlmod.html:309:running something via <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#system"><code>system</code></a>).</p>
html/pod/perlmod.html:315:compilation units, as are string <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#eval"><code>eval</code></a>s, code compiled using the
html/pod/perlmod.html:316:<code>(?{ })</code> construct in a regex, calls to <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#do"><code>do FILE</code></a>, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#require"><code>require FILE</code></a>,

html/pod/perlop.html:265:<p>Unary &quot;\&quot; creates a reference to whatever follows it.  See <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlreftut.html">the perlreftut manpage</a>

html/pod/perlop.html:296:operands <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#_a"><code>$a</code></a> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#_b"><code>$b</code></a>: If <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#_b"><code>$b</code></a> is positive, then <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#_a"><code>$a % $b</code></a> is
html/pod/perlop.html:297:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#_a"><code>$a</code></a> minus the largest multiple of <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#_b"><code>$b</code></a> that is not greater than
html/pod/perlop.html:298:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#_a"><code>$a</code></a>.  If <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#_b"><code>$b</code></a> is negative, then <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#_a"><code>$a % $b</code></a> is <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#_a"><code>$a</code></a> minus the
html/pod/perlop.html:299:smallest multiple of <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#_b"><code>$b</code></a> that is not less than <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#_a"><code>$a</code></a> (i.e. the
html/pod/perlop.html:301:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#_a"><code>$a</code></a> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#_b"><code>$b</code></a> are floating point values and the absolute value of
html/pod/perlop.html:302:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#_b"><code>$b</code></a> (that is <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#abs"><code>abs($b)</code></a>) is less than <code>(UV_MAX + 1)</code>, only
html/pod/perlop.html:303:the integer portion of <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#_a"><code>$a</code></a> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#_b"><code>$b</code></a> will be used in the operation
html/pod/perlop.html:305:If the absolute value of the right operand (<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#abs"><code>abs($b)</code></a>) is greater than
html/pod/perlop.html:309:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#_b"><code>$b</code></a> (<strong>not</strong> as the left operand <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#_a"><code>$a</code></a> like C function <code>fmod()</code>)
html/pod/perlop.html:310:and the absolute value less than that of <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#_b"><code>$b</code></a>.
html/pod/perlop.html:382:<p>Regarding precedence, the filetest operators, like <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#f"><code>-f</code></a>, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#m"><code>-M</code></a>, etc. are
html/pod/perlop.html:384:parenthesis rule.  That means, for example, that <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#f"><code>-f($file).&quot;.bak&quot;</code></a> is

html/pod/perlop.html:444:by the current locale if <code>use locale</code> is in effect.  See <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perllocale.html">the perllocale manpage</a>.</p>
html/pod/perlop.html:484:tests the left hand side's definedness instead of its truth.  Thus, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#_a"><code>$a // $b</code></a>
html/pod/perlop.html:485:is similar to <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#defined"><code>defined($a) || $b</code></a> (except that it returns the value of <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#_a"><code>$a</code></a>
html/pod/perlop.html:486:rather than the value of <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#defined"><code>defined($a)</code></a>) and is exactly equivalent to
html/pod/perlop.html:487:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#defined"><code>defined($a) ? $a : $b</code></a>.  This is very useful for providing default values
html/pod/perlop.html:488:for variables.  If you actually want to test if at least one of <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#_a"><code>$a</code></a> and
html/pod/perlop.html:489:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#_b"><code>$b</code></a> is defined, use <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#defined"><code>defined($a // $b)</code></a>.</p>
html/pod/perlop.html:559:input line number (the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>$.</code></a> variable).</p>

html/pod/perlop.html:902:<p>All systems use the virtual <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#n"><code>&quot;\n&quot;</code></a> to represent a line terminator,
html/pod/perlop.html:906:systems read <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#r"><code>&quot;\r&quot;</code></a> as ASCII CR and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#n"><code>&quot;\n&quot;</code></a> as ASCII LF.  For example,
html/pod/perlop.html:908:printing <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#n"><code>&quot;\n&quot;</code></a> may emit no actual data.  In general, use <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#n"><code>&quot;\n&quot;</code></a> when

html/pod/perlop.html:1148:The position after the last match can be read or set using the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#pos"><code>pos()</code></a>
html/pod/perlop.html:1149:function; see <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#pos">pos in the perlfunc manpage</a>.   A failed match normally resets the
html/pod/perlop.html:1151:by adding the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#c"><code>/c</code></a> modifier (e.g. <a href="#m_"><code>m//gc</code></a>).  Modifying the target

html/pod/perlop.html:1160:<code>/g</code> match applied to it is the same as using the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#a"><code>\A</code></a> assertion to match

html/pod/perlop.html:1214:final match did indeed match <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#p"><code>p</code></a>, it's a good bet that you're running an
html/pod/perlop.html:1255:once between calls to the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#reset"><code>reset()</code></a> operator.  This is a useful

html/pod/perlop.html:1322:to be <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#eval"><code>eval</code></a>ed before being run as a Perl expression.</p>

html/pod/perlop.html:2004:<dt><strong><a name="m_the_pattern_of_s" class="item"><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#m"><code>m''</code></a>, the pattern of <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#s"><code>s'''</code></a></a></strong>
html/pod/perlop.html:2012:<dt><strong><a name="q_tr_y_the_replacement_of_s" class="item"><code>''</code>, <a href="#q_"><code>q//</code></a>, <code>tr'''</code>, <code>y'''</code>, the replacement of <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#s"><code>s'''</code></a></a></strong>
html/pod/perlop.html:2018:<code>\1</code> in the replacement of <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#s"><code>s'''</code></a> does not work as <code>$1</code>.</p>
html/pod/perlop.html:2025:case and quoting such as <code>\Q</code>, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#u"><code>\U</code></a>, and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#e"><code>\E</code></a> are not recognized.
html/pod/perlop.html:2026:The other escape sequences such as <code>\200</code> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#t"><code>\t</code></a> and backslashed
html/pod/perlop.html:2035:<p><code>\Q</code>, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#u"><code>\U</code></a>, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#u"><code>\u</code></a>, <code>\L</code>, <code>\l</code> (possibly paired with <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#e"><code>\E</code></a>) are
html/pod/perlop.html:2037:is converted to <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#quotemeta"><code>$foo . (quotemeta(&quot;baz&quot; . $bar))</code></a> internally.
html/pod/perlop.html:2038:The other escape sequences such as <code>\200</code> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#t"><code>\t</code></a> and backslashed
html/pod/perlop.html:2043:<p>Let it be stressed that <em>whatever falls between <code>\Q</code> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#e"><code>\E</code></a></em>
html/pod/perlop.html:2045:no <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#e"><code>\E</code></a> inside.  instead, it has <code>\Q</code>, <code>\\</code>, and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#e"><code>E</code></a>, so the
html/pod/perlop.html:2046:result is the same as for <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#e"><code>&quot;\\\\E&quot;</code></a>.  As a general rule, backslashes
html/pod/perlop.html:2047:between <code>\Q</code> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#e"><code>\E</code></a> may lead to counterintuitive results.  So,
html/pod/perlop.html:2048:<code>&quot;\Q\t\E&quot;</code> is converted to <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#quotemeta"><code>quotemeta(&quot;\t&quot;)</code></a>, which is the same
html/pod/perlop.html:2049:as <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#t"><code>&quot;\\\t&quot;</code></a> (since TAB is not alphanumeric).  Note also that:</p>
html/pod/perlop.html:2060:<p>Interpolated scalars and arrays are converted internally to the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#join"><code>join</code></a> and
html/pod/perlop.html:2104:<p>Processing of <code>\Q</code>, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#u"><code>\U</code></a>, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#u"><code>\u</code></a>, <code>\L</code>, <code>\l</code>, and interpolation
html/pod/perlop.html:2112:(that is, the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__w"><code>$^W</code></a> variable) was set.</p>
html/pod/perlop.html:2118:<p>Processing of <code>\Q</code>, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#u"><code>\U</code></a>, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#u"><code>\u</code></a>, <code>\L</code>, <code>\l</code>, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#e"><code>\E</code></a>,
html/pod/perlop.html:2125:As <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#c"><code>\c</code></a> is skipped at this step, <code>@</code> of <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#c"><code>\c@</code></a> in RE is possibly
html/pod/perlop.html:2127:even though the same text in <a href="#qq_"><code>qq//</code></a> gives interpolation of <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#c"><code>\c@</code></a>.</p>
html/pod/perlop.html:2131:a <code>#</code>-comment in a <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#x"><code>//x</code></a>-regular expression, no processing is
html/pod/perlop.html:2133:of the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#x"><code>//x</code></a> modifier is relevant.</p>
html/pod/perlop.html:2136:<p>Interpolation in patterns has several quirks: <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>$|</code></a>, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>$(</code></a>, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>$)</code></a>, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>@+</code></a>
html/pod/perlop.html:2137:and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>@-</code></a> are not interpolated, and constructs <code>$var[SOMETHING]</code> are
html/pod/perlop.html:2163:delimiter is <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#m"><code>m</code></a>, the modifier is <code>mx</code>, and after delimiter-removal the
html/pod/perlop.html:2183:<p>Whatever happens in the RE engine might be better discussed in <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlre.html">the perlre manpage</a>,
html/pod/perlop.html:2187:<p>This is another step where the presence of the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#x"><code>//x</code></a> modifier is
html/pod/perlop.html:2194:in the finite automaton (as with <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#b"><code>\b</code></a>).  Characters special to the
html/pod/perlop.html:2198:whitespace and <code>#</code>-style comments if <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#x"><code>//x</code></a> is present).</p>
html/pod/perlop.html:2214:switch documented in <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#command_switches">Command Switches in the perlrun manpage</a>.</p>
html/pod/perlop.html:2226:<p>It is at this stage that <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#split"><code>split()</code></a> silently optimizes <code>/^/</code> to
html/pod/perlop.html:2227:mean <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#m"><code>/^/m</code></a>.</p>
html/pod/perlop.html:2242:values is returned, one per line of output.  (You can set <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>$/</code></a> to use
html/pod/perlop.html:2245:returned in <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#_"><code>$?</code></a> (see <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html">the perlvar manpage</a> for the interpretation of <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#_"><code>$?</code></a>).

html/pod/perlop.html:2257:returns <code>''</code> the first time, followed by <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#undef"><code>undef</code></a> subsequently.</p>

html/pod/perlop.html:2357:<p>The &lt;&gt; symbol will return <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#undef"><code>undef</code></a> for end-of-file only once.

html/pod/perlop.html:2382:internal function directly as <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#glob"><code>glob($foo)</code></a>, which is probably the right
html/pod/perlop.html:2403:the next value each time it's called, or <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#undef"><code>undef</code></a> when the list has
html/pod/perlop.html:2404:run out.  As with filehandle reads, an automatic <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#defined"><code>defined</code></a> is
html/pod/perlop.html:2407:terminate the loop.  Again, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#undef"><code>undef</code></a> is returned only once.  So if

html/pod/perlopentut.html:89:<p>Perl's <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#open"><code>open</code></a> function was designed to mimic the way command-line
html/pod/perlopentut.html:111:<p>The <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#open"><code>open</code></a> function takes two arguments: the first is a filehandle,
html/pod/perlopentut.html:113:to open it.  <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#open"><code>open</code></a> returns true when it works, and when it fails,
html/pod/perlopentut.html:114:returns a false value and sets the special variable <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>$!</code></a> to reflect
html/pod/perlopentut.html:148:<p>This is not a bug, but a feature.  Because <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#open"><code>open</code></a> mimics the shell in
html/pod/perlopentut.html:153:<p>There is also a 3-argument version of <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#open"><code>open</code></a>, which lets you put the
html/pod/perlopentut.html:165:<p><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#open"><code>open</code></a>'s first argument can be a reference to a filehandle.  As of
html/pod/perlopentut.html:193:character.  That's also the case for Perl.  The <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#open"><code>open</code></a> call 
html/pod/perlopentut.html:195:<p>If the leading character is a pipe symbol, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#open"><code>open</code></a> starts up a new
html/pod/perlopentut.html:212:command?  If possible, Perl will detect the failure and set <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>$!</code></a> as
html/pod/perlopentut.html:217:indication.  In such a case, the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#open"><code>open</code></a> call will only indicate
html/pod/perlopentut.html:218:failure if Perl can't even run the shell.  See <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfaq8.html#how_can_i_capture_stderr_from_an_external_command">How can I capture STDERR from an external command? in the perlfaq8 manpage</a> to see how to cope with
html/pod/perlopentut.html:219:this.  There's also an explanation in <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlipc.html">the perlipc manpage</a>.</p>
html/pod/perlopentut.html:222:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlipc.html#bidirectional_communication_with_another_process">Bidirectional Communication with Another Process in the perlipc manpage</a></p>
html/pod/perlopentut.html:227:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#open"><code>open</code></a> function treats a file whose name is a single minus, &quot;-&quot;, in a
html/pod/perlopentut.html:234:a stealth <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#fork"><code>fork</code></a> hidden inside an <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#open"><code>open</code></a> call.  See

html/pod/perlopentut.html:261:Perl's <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#open"><code>open</code></a> is historically derived from the one in C's <code>fopen(3S)</code>,

html/pod/perlopentut.html:355:<p>It's not for nothing that this is called magic <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#argv"><code>&lt;ARGV&gt;</code></a>.

html/pod/perlopentut.html:394:<code>O_NOCTTY</code>, <code>O_NDELAY</code> and <code>O_LARGEFILE</code>.  Consult your <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#open"><code>open(2)</code></a>
html/pod/perlopentut.html:397:added to the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#sysopen"><code>sysopen()</code></a> flags because large files are the default.)</p>
html/pod/perlopentut.html:398:<p>Here's how to use <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#sysopen"><code>sysopen</code></a> to emulate the simple <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#open"><code>open</code></a> calls we had
html/pod/perlopentut.html:399:before.  We'll omit the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#die"><code>|| die $!</code></a> checks for clarity, but make sure
html/pod/perlopentut.html:401:the same, since <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#open"><code>open</code></a> will trim leading and trailing whitespace,

html/pod/perlopentut.html:442:<p>If you omit the MASK argument to <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#sysopen"><code>sysopen</code></a>, Perl uses the octal value
html/pod/perlopentut.html:446:by your process's current <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#umask"><code>umask</code></a>.  A umask is a number representing
html/pod/perlopentut.html:449:<p>For example, if your <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#umask"><code>umask</code></a> were 027, then the 020 part would
html/pod/perlopentut.html:452:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#sysopen"><code>sysopen</code></a> 0666 would create a file with mode 0640, since <code>0666 &amp; ~027</code>
html/pod/perlopentut.html:454:<p>You should seldom use the MASK argument to <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#sysopen"><code>sysopen()</code></a>.  That takes
html/pod/perlopentut.html:490:proper filehandle in the native Perl sense.  You'll have to use <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#fileno"><code>fileno()</code></a>
html/pod/perlopentut.html:514:<p>If you're using magic <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#argv"><code>&lt;ARGV&gt;</code></a>, you could even pass in as a

html/pod/perlopentut.html:540:use a slash.  Maybe <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#sysopen"><code>sysopen</code></a> isn't such a bad idea after all.</p>
html/pod/perlopentut.html:541:<p>If you want to use <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#argv"><code>&lt;ARGV&gt;</code></a> processing in a totally boring

html/pod/perlopentut.html:706:described in <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfaq8.html#how_do_i_read_and_write_the_serial_port">How do I read and write the serial port? in the perlfaq8 manpage</a>

html/pod/perlothrtut.html:550:<h2><a name="controlling_access__lock__">Controlling access: <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#lock"><code>lock()</code></a></a></h2>
html/pod/perlothrtut.html:551:<p>The <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#lock"><code>lock()</code></a> function takes a variable (or subroutine, but we'll get to
html/pod/perlothrtut.html:554:the lock.  Using <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#lock"><code>lock()</code></a> is straightforward:</p>
html/pod/perlothrtut.html:579:<p><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#lock"><code>lock()</code></a> blocks the thread until the variable being locked is
html/pod/perlothrtut.html:580:available.  When <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#lock"><code>lock()</code></a> returns, your thread can be sure that no other
html/pod/perlothrtut.html:586:locking that <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#flock"><code>flock()</code></a> gives you.  Locked subroutines behave differently,
html/pod/perlothrtut.html:593:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#lock"><code>lock()</code></a> on the variable goes out of scope.</p>
html/pod/perlpacktut.html:79:<p>perlpacktut - tutorial on <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#pack"><code>pack</code></a> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#unpack"><code>unpack</code></a></p>
html/pod/perlpacktut.html:84:<p><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#pack"><code>pack</code></a> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#unpack"><code>unpack</code></a> are two functions for transforming data according
html/pod/perlpacktut.html:100:representational conversion provided by <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#pack"><code>pack</code></a> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#unpack"><code>unpack</code></a> is an
html/pod/perlpacktut.html:101:excellent alternative. The <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#pack"><code>pack</code></a> function converts values to a byte
html/pod/perlpacktut.html:103:the so-called &quot;template&quot; argument. <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#unpack"><code>unpack</code></a> is the reverse process,
html/pod/perlpacktut.html:112:is not available as a Perl function: <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#syscall"><code>syscall</code></a> requires you to provide
html/pod/perlpacktut.html:118:sequence and a string of hexadecimal digits. Let's use <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#unpack"><code>unpack</code></a>, since
html/pod/perlpacktut.html:138:we note that <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#unpack"><code>unpack</code></a> with the template code <code>H</code> converts the contents
html/pod/perlpacktut.html:149:<p>Since we feed a list of ten 2-digit hexadecimal strings to <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#pack"><code>pack</code></a>, the
html/pod/perlpacktut.html:162:<p>How do we do it? You might think first to use <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#split"><code>split</code></a>; however, since
html/pod/perlpacktut.html:163:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#split"><code>split</code></a> collapses blank fields, you'll never know whether a record was
html/pod/perlpacktut.html:164:income or expenditure. Oops. Well, you could always use <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#substr"><code>substr</code></a>:</p>
html/pod/perlpacktut.html:188:if you use the right tools. <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#pack"><code>pack</code></a> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#unpack"><code>unpack</code></a> are designed to help
html/pod/perlpacktut.html:190:look at a solution with <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#unpack"><code>unpack</code></a>:</p>
html/pod/perlpacktut.html:207:column 10 - ten characters wide. The <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#pack"><code>pack</code></a>-ese for &quot;character&quot; is
html/pod/perlpacktut.html:208:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#a"><code>A</code></a>, and ten of them are <code>A10</code>. So if we just wanted to extract the
html/pod/perlpacktut.html:213:we want to skip over that. The <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#x"><code>x</code></a> template means &quot;skip forward&quot;, so we

html/pod/perlpacktut.html:880:<p>And that's where the first quirk strikes: <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#pack"><code>pack</code></a> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#unpack"><code>unpack</code></a>
