html/pod/perlpacktut.html:898:[Probably a Cray, where <code>short</code>s, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#int"><code>int</code></a>s and <code>long</code>s are all 8 bytes. :-)]</p>
html/pod/perlpacktut.html:923:<p>The output line can be used as a template in a <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#pack"><code>pack</code></a> or <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#unpack"><code>unpack</code></a> call:</p>
html/pod/perlpacktut.html:932:<p>Neither using offsets nor adding <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#x"><code>x</code></a>'s to bridge the gaps is satisfactory.
html/pod/perlpacktut.html:942:done by enclosing the appropriate pack code in brackets: <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#s"><code>[s]</code></a>. So, here's
html/pod/perlpacktut.html:1016:<p>Template code <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#p"><code>P</code></a> promises to pack a &quot;pointer to a fixed length string&quot;.
html/pod/perlpacktut.html:1022:<p>But wait: doesn't <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#pack"><code>pack</code></a> just return a sequence of bytes? How can we pass this
html/pod/perlpacktut.html:1025:address from the bytes returned by <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#pack"><code>pack</code></a>.</p>
html/pod/perlpacktut.html:1032:where a pointer is expected. The <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#read"><code>read(2)</code></a> system call comes to mind:</p>
html/pod/perlpacktut.html:1035:<p>After reading <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html">the perlfunc manpage</a> explaining how to use <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#syscall"><code>syscall</code></a> we can write

html/pod/perlpacktut.html:1057:produce the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#undef"><code>undef</code></a> value) we have a start address - but then what?
html/pod/perlpacktut.html:1059:it's up to you to specify the actual size as an explicit length after <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#p"><code>P</code></a>.</p>
html/pod/perlpacktut.html:1063:<p>As a consequence, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#pack"><code>pack</code></a> ignores any number or <code>*</code> after <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#p"><code>P</code></a>.</p>
html/pod/perlpacktut.html:1064:<p>Now that we have seen <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#p"><code>P</code></a> at work, we might as well give <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#p"><code>p</code></a> a whirl.
html/pod/perlpacktut.html:1066:answer lies behind the simple fact that an <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#unpack"><code>unpack</code></a> with <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#p"><code>p</code></a> promises
html/pod/perlpacktut.html:1073:implied by the string's length, a number after pack code <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#p"><code>p</code></a> is a repeat
html/pod/perlpacktut.html:1074:count, not a length as after <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#p"><code>P</code></a>.</p>
html/pod/perlpacktut.html:1075:<p>Using <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#pack"><code>pack(..., $x)</code></a> with <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#p"><code>P</code></a> or <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#p"><code>p</code></a> to get the address where <code>$x</code> is

html/pod/perlport.html:160:<p>Perl uses <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#n"><code>\n</code></a> to represent the &quot;logical&quot; newline, where what is
html/pod/perlport.html:161:logical may depend on the platform in use.  In MacPerl, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#n"><code>\n</code></a> always
html/pod/perlport.html:162:means <code>\015</code>.  In DOSish perls, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#n"><code>\n</code></a> usually means <code>\012</code>, but
html/pod/perlport.html:167:<p>To trim trailing newlines from text lines use <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#chomp"><code>chomp()</code></a>.  With default 
html/pod/perlport.html:168:settings that function looks for a trailing <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#n"><code>\n</code></a> character and thus 
html/pod/perlport.html:172:before using <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#chomp"><code>chomp()</code></a>.</p>
html/pod/perlport.html:174:in using <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#seek"><code>seek</code></a> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#tell"><code>tell</code></a> on a file accessed in &quot;text&quot; mode.
html/pod/perlport.html:175:Stick to <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#seek"><code>seek</code></a>-ing to locations you got from <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#tell"><code>tell</code></a> (and no
html/pod/perlport.html:176:others), and you are usually free to use <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#seek"><code>seek</code></a> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#tell"><code>tell</code></a> even
html/pod/perlport.html:177:in &quot;text&quot; mode.  Using <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#seek"><code>seek</code></a> or <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#tell"><code>tell</code></a> or other file operations
html/pod/perlport.html:179:can usually <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#seek"><code>seek</code></a> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#tell"><code>tell</code></a> with arbitrary values in safety.</p>
html/pod/perlport.html:180:<p>A common misconception in socket programming is that <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#n"><code>\n</code></a> eq <code>\012</code>
html/pod/perlport.html:183:the logical <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#n"><code>\n</code></a> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#r"><code>\r</code></a> (carriage return) are not reliable.</p>
html/pod/perlport.html:194:separator <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>$/</code></a> is <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#n"><code>\n</code></a>, but robust socket code will recognize as
html/pod/perlport.html:237:<p>These are just the most common definitions of <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#n"><code>\n</code></a> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#r"><code>\r</code></a> in Perl.
html/pod/perlport.html:270:connections use the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#pack"><code>pack</code></a> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#unpack"><code>unpack</code></a> formats <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#n"><code>n</code></a> and <code>N</code>, the
html/pod/perlport.html:427:like file permissions or owners.  Remember to <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#close"><code>close</code></a> files when you
html/pod/perlport.html:428:are done with them.  Don't <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#unlink"><code>unlink</code></a> or <a href="#rename"><code>rename</code></a> an open file.  Don't
html/pod/perlport.html:429:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#tie"><code>tie</code></a> or <a href="#open"><code>open</code></a> a file already tied or opened; <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#untie"><code>untie</code></a> or <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#close"><code>close</code></a>
html/pod/perlport.html:439:<p>Don't assume that a single <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#unlink"><code>unlink</code></a> completely gets rid of the file:
html/pod/perlport.html:441:filesystems, and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#unlink"><code>unlink()</code></a> removes only the most recent one (it doesn't
html/pod/perlport.html:449:<p>Don't count on a specific environment variable existing in <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#_env"><code>%ENV</code></a>.
html/pod/perlport.html:450:Don't count on <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#_env"><code>%ENV</code></a> entries being case-sensitive, or even
html/pod/perlport.html:451:case-preserving.  Don't try to clear %ENV by saying <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#_env"><code>%ENV = ();</code></a>, or,
html/pod/perlport.html:452:if you really have to, make it conditional on <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__o"><code>$^O ne 'VMS'</code></a> since in
html/pod/perlport.html:453:VMS the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#_env"><code>%ENV</code></a> table is much more than a per-process key-value string
html/pod/perlport.html:463:<p>Don't count on signals or <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#_sig"><code>%SIG</code></a> for anything.</p>
html/pod/perlport.html:464:<p>Don't count on filename globbing.  Use <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#opendir"><code>opendir</code></a>, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#readdir"><code>readdir</code></a>, and
html/pod/perlport.html:465:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#closedir"><code>closedir</code></a> instead.</p>
html/pod/perlport.html:468:<p>Don't count on specific values of <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>$!</code></a>, neither numeric nor
html/pod/perlport.html:472:by the Errno module, like ENOENT.  And don't trust on the values of <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>$!</code></a>
html/pod/perlport.html:536:<code>``</code>, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlop.html#qx_"><code>qx//</code></a>, <a href="#open"><code>open</code></a> with a <code>|</code>, nor any of the other things
html/pod/perlport.html:562:<p>Do not use either the bare result of <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#pack"><code>pack(&quot;N&quot;, 10, 20, 30, 40)</code></a> or
html/pod/perlport.html:600:work with any DBM module.  See <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/lib/AnyDBM_File.html">the AnyDBM_File manpage</a> for more details.</p>
html/pod/perlport.html:638:<p>Assume nothing about numerical values (<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#ord"><code>ord</code></a>, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#chr"><code>chr</code></a>) of characters.
html/pod/perlport.html:640:example symbolic character classes like <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#print"><code>[:print:]</code></a>.</p>

html/pod/perlpragma.html:107:prevent its <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#import"><code>import</code></a> being called.</p>
html/pod/perlpragma.html:143:<p>Hence the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#import"><code>import</code></a> and <code>unimport</code> routines are called at <strong>compile time</strong>
html/pod/perlpragma.html:145:<p>User pragmata store their state by writing to the magical hash <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__h"><code>%^H</code></a>,
html/pod/perlpragma.html:146:hence these two routines manipulate it. The state information in <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__h"><code>%^H</code></a> is
html/pod/perlpragma.html:147:stored in the optree, and can be retrieved at runtime with <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#caller"><code>caller()</code></a>, at
html/pod/perlpragma.html:151:user's script. This uses <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#caller"><code>caller()</code></a> to determine the value of
html/pod/perlpragma.html:163:integers (signed and unsigned), strings or <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#undef"><code>undef</code></a> - references and
html/pod/perlpragma.html:165:or complex structures, you should serialise them, for example with <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#pack"><code>pack</code></a>.
html/pod/perlpragma.html:166:The deletion of a hash key from <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__h"><code>%^H</code></a> is recorded, and as ever can be
html/pod/perlpragma.html:167:distinguished from the existence of a key with value <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#undef"><code>undef</code></a> with
html/pod/perlpragma.html:168:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#exists"><code>exists</code></a>.</p>
html/pod/perlpragma.html:170:are retrieved via <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#caller"><code>caller</code></a> and converted back, as this will not be threadsafe.
html/pod/perlre.html:69:introduction is available in <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrequick.html">the perlrequick manpage</a>, and a longer tutorial
html/pod/perlre.html:70:introduction is available in <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlretut.html">the perlretut manpage</a>.</p>
html/pod/perlre.html:73:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlop.html#m_"><code>m//</code></a>, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlop.html#s_"><code>s///</code></a>, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlop.html#qr_"><code>qr//</code></a> and <code>??</code> in <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlop.html#regexp_quote_like_operators">Regexp Quote-Like Operators in the perlop manpage</a>.</p>
html/pod/perlre.html:80:is used by Perl are detailed in <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlop.html#regexp_quote_like_operators">Regexp Quote-Like Operators in the perlop manpage</a> and

html/pod/perlre.html:579:match.  <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>$+</code></a> returns whatever the last bracket match matched.
html/pod/perlre.html:580:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>$&amp;</code></a> returns the entire matched string.  (At one point <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#_0"><code>$0</code></a> did
html/pod/perlre.html:581:also, but now it returns the name of the program.)  <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>$`</code></a> returns
html/pod/perlre.html:582:everything before the matched string.  <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>$'</code></a> returns everything
html/pod/perlre.html:583:after the matched string. And <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__n"><code>$^N</code></a> contains whatever was matched by
html/pod/perlre.html:584:the most-recently closed group (submatch). <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__n"><code>$^N</code></a> can be used in
html/pod/perlre.html:588:set (<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>$+</code></a>, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>$&amp;</code></a>, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>$`</code></a>, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>$'</code></a>, and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__n"><code>$^N</code></a>) are all dynamically scoped
html/pod/perlre.html:590:match, whichever comes first.  (See <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlsyn.html#compound_statements">Compound Statements in the perlsyn manpage</a>.)</p>

html/pod/perlre.html:1321:<p>For example: <code>^(?&gt;a*)ab</code> will never match, since <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#a"><code>(?&gt;a*)</code></a>

html/pod/perlre.html:1326:group <code>ab</code> (see <a href="#backtracking">Backtracking</a>).  In particular, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#a"><code>a*</code></a> inside

html/pod/perlre.html:1333:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#a"><code>a+</code></a>, and the following <a href="#1"><code>\1</code></a> eats the matched string; it therefore
html/pod/perlre.html:1379:the time when used on a similar string with 1000000 <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#a"><code>a</code></a>s.  Be aware,
html/pod/perlre.html:1387:This was only 4 times slower on a string with 1000000 <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#a"><code>a</code></a>s.</p>

html/pod/perlre.html:2029:<p>The <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#o"><code>o?</code></a> matches at the beginning of <code>'foo'</code>, and since the position
html/pod/perlre.html:2030:in the string is not moved by the match, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#o"><code>o?</code></a> would match again and again

html/pod/perlre.html:2077:the matched string, and is reset by each assignment to <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#pos"><code>pos()</code></a>.

html/pod/perlre.html:2088:(in these examples <a href="#s"><code>S</code></a> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#t"><code>T</code></a> are regular subexpressions).</p>
html/pod/perlre.html:2091:substring <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#a"><code>&quot;a&quot;</code></a> or <code>&quot;ab&quot;</code>?  One way to describe which substring is
html/pod/perlre.html:2103:below <a href="#s"><code>S</code></a> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#t"><code>T</code></a> are regular subexpressions.</p>
html/pod/perlre.html:2108:<p>Consider two possible matches, <code>AB</code> and <code>A'B'</code>, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#a"><code>A</code></a> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#a"><code>A'</code></a> are
html/pod/perlre.html:2110:which can be matched by <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#t"><code>T</code></a>.</p>
html/pod/perlre.html:2113:<p>If <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#a"><code>A</code></a> is better match for <a href="#s"><code>S</code></a> than <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#a"><code>A'</code></a>, <code>AB</code> is a better
html/pod/perlre.html:2117:<p>If <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#a"><code>A</code></a> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#a"><code>A'</code></a> coincide: <code>AB</code> is a better match than <code>AB'</code> if
html/pod/perlre.html:2118:<code>B</code> is better match for <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#t"><code>T</code></a> than <code>B'</code>.</p>

html/pod/perlreapi.html:741:purposes when embedding compiled regexes into larger patterns with <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlop.html#qr_"><code>qr//</code></a>.</p>
html/pod/perlreapi.html:752:<p>Originally part of <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlreguts.html">the perlreguts manpage</a>.</p>
html/pod/perlrebackslash.html:142:is found in <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlre.html">the perlre manpage</a>.</p>
html/pod/perlrebackslash.html:182:it. Perl won't warn then. See also <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlop.html#gory_details_of_parsing_quoted_constructs">Gory details of parsing quoted constructs in the perlop manpage</a>.</p>
html/pod/perlrebackslash.html:254:<p><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#b"><code>\b</code></a> is only the backspace character inside a character class. Outside a
html/pod/perlrebackslash.html:255:character class, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#b"><code>\b</code></a> is a word/non-word boundary.</p>
html/pod/perlrebackslash.html:261:<p><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#n"><code>\n</code></a> matches a logical newline. Perl will convert between <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#n"><code>\n</code></a> and your
html/pod/perlrebackslash.html:274:<p><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#c"><code>\c</code></a> is used to denote a control character; the character following <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#c"><code>\c</code></a>
html/pod/perlrebackslash.html:277:character following <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#c"><code>\c</code></a> doesn't matter: <code>\cM</code> and <code>\cm</code> match the same
html/pod/perlrebackslash.html:293:a name it doesn't know about. For more details, see <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/lib/charnames.html">the charnames manpage</a>.</p>
html/pod/perlrebackslash.html:355:<p>Hexadecimal escapes start with <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#x"><code>\x</code></a> and are then either followed by
html/pod/perlrebackslash.html:382:it, while <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#u"><code>\u</code></a> will uppercase (or, more accurately, titlecase) the
html/pod/perlrebackslash.html:384:functions <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#lcfirst"><code>lcfirst</code></a> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#ucfirst"><code>ucfirst</code></a>).</p>
html/pod/perlrebackslash.html:386:<code>\L</code> or <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#u"><code>\U</code></a>, which will lowercase/uppercase all characters following
html/pod/perlrebackslash.html:388:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#e"><code>\E</code></a>, whatever comes first. They perform similar functionality as the
html/pod/perlrebackslash.html:389:functions <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#lc"><code>lc</code></a> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#uc"><code>uc</code></a> do.</p>
html/pod/perlrebackslash.html:390:<p><code>\Q</code> is used to escape all characters following, up to the next <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#e"><code>\E</code></a>
html/pod/perlrebackslash.html:393:between <code>\Q</code> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#e"><code>\E</code></a> is matched literally, and will not be interpreted
html/pod/perlrebackslash.html:413:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrecharclass.html">the perlrecharclass manpage</a>.</p>
html/pod/perlrebackslash.html:414:<p><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#w"><code>\w</code></a> is a character class that matches any <em>word</em> character (letters,
html/pod/perlrebackslash.html:415:digits, underscore). <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#d"><code>\d</code></a> is a character class that matches any digit,
html/pod/perlrebackslash.html:416:while the character class <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#s"><code>\s</code></a> matches any white space character.
html/pod/perlrebackslash.html:417:New in perl 5.10.0 are the classes <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#h"><code>\h</code></a> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#v"><code>\v</code></a> which match horizontal
html/pod/perlrebackslash.html:419:<p>The uppercase variants (<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#w"><code>\W</code></a>, <code>\D</code>, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#s"><code>\S</code></a>, <code>\H</code>, and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#v"><code>\V</code></a>) are
html/pod/perlrebackslash.html:426:<p><code>\pP</code> (where <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#p"><code>P</code></a> is a single letter) and <code>\p{Property}</code> are used to
html/pod/perlrebackslash.html:431:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrecharclass.html#backslashed_sequences">Backslashed sequences in the perlrecharclass manpage</a> and
html/pod/perlrebackslash.html:432:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlunicode.html#unicode_character_properties">Unicode Character Properties in the perlunicode manpage</a>.</p>
html/pod/perlrebackslash.html:514:<p><a href="#a"><code>\A</code></a> only matches at the beginning of the string. If the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#m"><code>/m</code></a> modifier
html/pod/perlrebackslash.html:515:isn't used, then <a href="#a"><code>/\A/</code></a> is equivalent with <code>/^/</code>. However, if the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#m"><code>/m</code></a>
html/pod/perlrebackslash.html:517:of <a href="#a"><code>/\A/</code></a> isn't changed by the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#m"><code>/m</code></a> modifier. <a href="#a"><code>\A</code></a> matches at the beginning
html/pod/perlrebackslash.html:518:of the string regardless whether the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#m"><code>/m</code></a> modifier is used.</p>
html/pod/perlrebackslash.html:524:<p><code>\z</code> and <code>\Z</code> match at the end of the string. If the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#m"><code>/m</code></a> modifier isn't
html/pod/perlrebackslash.html:527:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#m"><code>/m</code></a> modifier is used, then <code>/$/</code> matches at internal newlines, but the
html/pod/perlrebackslash.html:528:meaning of <code>/\Z/</code> isn't changed by the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#m"><code>/m</code></a> modifier. <code>\Z</code> matches at
html/pod/perlrebackslash.html:530:the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#m"><code>/m</code></a> modifier is used.</p>
html/pod/perlrebackslash.html:555:<p><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#b"><code>\b</code></a> matches at any place between a word and a non-word character; <code>\B</code>
html/pod/perlrebackslash.html:556:matches at any place between characters where <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#b"><code>\b</code></a> doesn't match. <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#b"><code>\b</code></a>
html/pod/perlrebackslash.html:558:the end of the source string; so <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#b"><code>\b</code></a> will match at the beginning (or end)
html/pod/perlrebackslash.html:608:not included in <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>$&amp;</code></a> - and will not be replaced if the pattern is
html/pod/perlrebackslash.html:609:used in a substitution. This will allow you to write <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlop.html#s_"><code>s/PAT1 \K PAT2/REPL/x</code></a>
html/pod/perlrebackslash.html:610:instead of <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlop.html#s_"><code>s/(PAT1) PAT2/${1}REPL/x</code></a> or <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlop.html#s_"><code>s/(?&lt;=PAT1) PAT2/REPL/x</code></a>.</p>
html/pod/perlrebackslash.html:620:a newline by Unicode. This includes all characters matched by <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#v"><code>\v</code></a>
html/pod/perlrecharclass.html:87:is found in <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlre.html">the perlre manpage</a>.</p>
html/pod/perlrecharclass.html:104:for the entire regular expression using the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#s"><code>/s</code></a> modifier, or
html/pod/perlrecharclass.html:105:locally using <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#s"><code>(?s)</code></a>.</p>
html/pod/perlrecharclass.html:123:are character class; for a full list, see <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrebackslash.html">the perlrebackslash manpage</a>.</p>
html/pod/perlrecharclass.html:142:<p><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#d"><code>\d</code></a> matches a single character that is considered to be a <em>digit</em>.
html/pod/perlrecharclass.html:144:the source string. If the source string is in UTF-8 format, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#d"><code>\d</code></a>
html/pod/perlrecharclass.html:148:a locale, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#d"><code>\d</code></a> matches the digits '0' to '9'.
html/pod/perlrecharclass.html:150:<p>Any character that isn't matched by <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#d"><code>\d</code></a> will be matched by <code>\D</code>.</p>
html/pod/perlrecharclass.html:154:<p><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#w"><code>\w</code></a> matches a single <em>word</em> character: an alphanumeric character
html/pod/perlrecharclass.html:157:of the string. If it's in UTF-8 format, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#w"><code>\w</code></a> matches those characters
html/pod/perlrecharclass.html:160:If the source string isn't in UTF-8 format, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#w"><code>\w</code></a> matches those characters
html/pod/perlrecharclass.html:162:a locale in effect, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#w"><code>\w</code></a> matches the ASCII letters, digits and the
html/pod/perlrecharclass.html:164:<p>Any character that isn't matched by <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#w"><code>\w</code></a> will be matched by <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#w"><code>\W</code></a>.</p>
html/pod/perlrecharclass.html:168:<p><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#s"><code>\s</code></a> matches any single character that is consider white space. In the
html/pod/perlrecharclass.html:169:ASCII range, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#s"><code>\s</code></a> matches the horizontal tab (<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#t"><code>\t</code></a>), the new line
html/pod/perlrecharclass.html:170:(<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#n"><code>\n</code></a>), the form feed (<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#f"><code>\f</code></a>), the carriage return (<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#r"><code>\r</code></a>), and the
html/pod/perlrecharclass.html:171:space (the vertical tab, <code>\cK</code> is not matched by <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#s"><code>\s</code></a>).  The exact set
html/pod/perlrecharclass.html:172:of characters matched by <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#s"><code>\s</code></a> depends on whether the source string is
html/pod/perlrecharclass.html:173:in UTF-8 format. If it is, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#s"><code>\s</code></a> matches what is considered white space
html/pod/perlrecharclass.html:174:in the Unicode database. Otherwise, if there is a locale in effect, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#s"><code>\s</code></a>
html/pod/perlrecharclass.html:176:a locale, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#s"><code>\s</code></a> matches the five characters mentioned in the beginning
html/pod/perlrecharclass.html:177:of this paragraph.  Perhaps the most notable difference is that <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#s"><code>\s</code></a>
html/pod/perlrecharclass.html:180:<p>Any character that isn't matched by <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#s"><code>\s</code></a> will be matched by <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#s"><code>\S</code></a>.</p>
html/pod/perlrecharclass.html:181:<p><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#h"><code>\h</code></a> will match any character that is considered horizontal white space;
html/pod/perlrecharclass.html:184:<p><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#v"><code>\v</code></a> will match any character that is considered vertical white space;
html/pod/perlrecharclass.html:186:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#v"><code>\V</code></a> will match any character that is not considered vertical white space.</p>
html/pod/perlrecharclass.html:190:class. Details are discussed in <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrebackslash.html">the perlrebackslash manpage</a>.</p>
html/pod/perlrecharclass.html:191:<p><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#h"><code>\h</code></a>, <code>\H</code>, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#v"><code>\v</code></a>, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#v"><code>\V</code></a>, and <code>\R</code> are new in perl 5.10.0.</p>
html/pod/perlrecharclass.html:192:<p>Note that unlike <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#s"><code>\s</code></a>, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#d"><code>\d</code></a> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#w"><code>\w</code></a>, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#h"><code>\h</code></a> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#v"><code>\v</code></a> always match
html/pod/perlrecharclass.html:196:<p>One might think that <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#s"><code>\s</code></a> is equivalent with <code>[\h\v]</code>. This is not true.
html/pod/perlrecharclass.html:197:The vertical tab (<code>&quot;\x0b&quot;</code>) is not matched by <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#s"><code>\s</code></a>, it is however
html/pod/perlrecharclass.html:200:(<code>&quot;\xA0&quot;</code>) are not matched by <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#s"><code>\s</code></a>, but are by <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#v"><code>\v</code></a> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#h"><code>\h</code></a> respectively.
html/pod/perlrecharclass.html:202:no-break space are matched by <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#s"><code>\s</code></a>.</p>
html/pod/perlrecharclass.html:204:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#s"><code>\s</code></a>, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#h"><code>\h</code></a> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#v"><code>\v</code></a>.</p>
html/pod/perlrecharclass.html:239:<p>NEXT LINE and NO-BREAK SPACE only match <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#s"><code>\s</code></a> if the source string is in
html/pod/perlrecharclass.html:244:<p>It is worth noting that <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#d"><code>\d</code></a>, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#w"><code>\w</code></a>, etc, match single characters, not
html/pod/perlrecharclass.html:246:use <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#d"><code>\d+</code></a>; to match a word, use <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#w"><code>\w+</code></a>.</p>

html/pod/perlrecharclass.html:294:This matches one of <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#a"><code>a</code></a>, <code>e</code>, <code>i</code>, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#o"><code>o</code></a> or <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#u"><code>u</code></a>. html/pod/perlrecharclass.html:321:<p>The sequence <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#b"><code>\b</code></a> is special inside a bracketed character class. While
html/pod/perlrecharclass.html:322:outside the character class <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#b"><code>\b</code></a> is an assertion indicating a point

html/pod/perlrecharclass.html:425:and the letters <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#a"><code>a</code></a>, <code>l</code>, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#p"><code>p</code></a> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#h"><code>h</code></a>.</p>
html/pod/perlrecharclass.html:444:<p>Most POSIX character classes have <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#p"><code>\p</code></a> counterparts. The difference

html/pod/perlrecharclass.html:476:Latin character sets, and Unicode), as is the character <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#ord"><code>ord()</code></a> value

html/pod/perlrequick.html:245:<p>The <strong>word&nbsp;anchor</strong>&nbsp; <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#b"><code>\b</code></a> matches a boundary between a word

html/pod/perlrequick.html:338:<p><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#a"><code>a*</code></a> = match 'a' 0 or more times, i.e., any number of times</p>
html/pod/perlrequick.html:341:<p><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#a"><code>a+</code></a> = match 'a' 1 or more times, i.e., at least once</p>
html/pod/perlrequick.html:344:<p><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#a"><code>a{n,m}</code></a> = match at least <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#n"><code>n</code></a> times, but not more than <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#m"><code>m</code></a>
html/pod/perlrequick.html:348:<p><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#a"><code>a{n,}</code></a> = match at least <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#n"><code>n</code></a> or more times</p>
html/pod/perlrequick.html:351:<p><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#a"><code>a{n}</code></a> = match exactly <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#n"><code>n</code></a> times</p>
html/pod/perlrequick.html:384:<code>$pattern</code> won't be changing, use the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#o"><code>//o</code></a> modifier, to only
html/pod/perlrequick.html:386:substitutions at all, use the special delimiter <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#m"><code>m''</code></a>:</p>
html/pod/perlrequick.html:395:You can get or set the position with the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#pos"><code>pos()</code></a> function.
html/pod/perlrequick.html:409:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#c"><code>//c</code></a>, as in <code>/regex/gc</code>.</p>
html/pod/perlrequick.html:420:<p>Search and replace is performed using <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlop.html#s_"><code>s/regex/replacement/modifiers</code></a>.
html/pod/perlrequick.html:423:also used here to associate a string with <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlop.html#s_"><code>s///</code></a>.  If matching
html/pod/perlrequick.html:424:against <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>$_</code></a>, the <a&nbsp;href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>$_&nbsp;=~</code></a>&nbsp; can be dropped.  If there is a match,
html/pod/perlrequick.html:425:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlop.html#s_"><code>s///</code></a> returns the number of substitutions made, otherwise it returns
html/pod/perlrequick.html:433:<p>With the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlop.html#s_"><code>s///</code></a> operator, the matched variables <code>$1</code>, <code>$2</code>, etc.
html/pod/perlrequick.html:435:the global modifier, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlop.html#s_"><code>s///g</code></a> will search and replace all occurrences
html/pod/perlrequick.html:442:<p>The evaluation modifier <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlop.html#s_"><code>s///e</code></a> wraps an <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#eval"><code>eval{...}</code></a> around the
html/pod/perlrequick.html:453:<p>The last example shows that <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlop.html#s_"><code>s///</code></a> can use other delimiters, such as
html/pod/perlrequick.html:454:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#s"><code>s!!!</code></a> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#s"><code>s{}{}</code></a>, and even <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#s"><code>s{}//</code></a>.  If single quotes are used
html/pod/perlrequick.html:455:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#s"><code>s'''</code></a>, then the regex and replacement are treated as single quoted
html/pod/perlrequick.html:485:<p>Since the first character of $x matched the regex, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#split"><code>split</code></a> prepended
html/pod/perlrequick.html:497:regexes, see <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlretut.html">the perlretut manpage</a> and for the reference page, see <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlre.html">the perlre manpage</a>.</p>
html/pod/perlreref.html:63:For full information see <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlre.html">the perlre manpage</a> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlop.html">the perlop manpage</a>, as well
html/pod/perlreref.html:77:<p><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlop.html#m_"><code>m/pattern/msixpogc</code></a> searches a string for a pattern match,
html/pod/perlreref.html:91:operator and the following ones. The leading <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#m"><code>m</code></a> can be omitted
html/pod/perlreref.html:93:<p><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlop.html#qr_"><code>qr/pattern/msixpo</code></a> lets you store a regex in a variable,
html/pod/perlreref.html:94:or pass one around. Modifiers as for <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlop.html#m_"><code>m//</code></a>, and are stored
html/pod/perlreref.html:96:<p><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlop.html#s_"><code>s/pattern/replacement/msixpogce</code></a> substitutes matches of
html/pod/perlreref.html:97:'pattern' with 'replacement'. Modifiers as for <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlop.html#m_"><code>m//</code></a>,
html/pod/perlreref.html:103:<p><code>?pattern?</code> is like <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlop.html#m_"><code>m/pattern/</code></a> but matches only once. No alternate
html/pod/perlreref.html:104:delimiters can be used.  Must be reset with <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#reset"><code>reset()</code></a>.</p>
html/pod/perlreref.html:164:The first six are locale aware, all are Unicode aware. See <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perllocale.html">the perllocale manpage</a>
html/pod/perlreref.html:165:and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlunicode.html">the perlunicode manpage</a> for details.</p>
html/pod/perlreref.html:286:<p>The use of <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>$`</code></a>, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>$&amp;</code></a> or <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>$'</code></a> will slow down <strong>all</strong> regex use
html/pod/perlreref.html:287:within your program. Consult <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html">the perlvar manpage</a> for <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>@-</code></a>
html/pod/perlreref.html:289:See also <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/Devel/SawAmpersand.html">the Devel::SawAmpersand manpage</a>. Starting with Perl 5.10, you
html/pod/perlreref.html:290:can also use the equivalent variables <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#___prematch_"><code>${^PREMATCH}</code></a>, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#___match_"><code>${^MATCH}</code></a>
html/pod/perlreref.html:291:and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#___postmatch_"><code>${^POSTMATCH}</code></a>, but for them to be defined, you have to
html/pod/perlreref.html:292:specify the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#p"><code>/p</code></a> (preserve) modifier on your regular expression.</p>
html/pod/perlreref.html:319:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#u"><code>\U</code></a>, and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#u"><code>\u</code></a>.  For Titlecase, see <a href="#titlecase">Titlecase</a>.</p>
html/pod/perlreref.html:340:<p><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlretut.html">the perlretut manpage</a> for a tutorial on regular expressions.</p>
html/pod/perlreref.html:343:<p><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrequick.html">the perlrequick manpage</a> for a rapid tutorial.</p>
html/pod/perlreref.html:346:<p><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlre.html">the perlre manpage</a> for more details.</p>
html/pod/perlreref.html:349:<p><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html">the perlvar manpage</a> for details on the variables.</p>
html/pod/perlreref.html:352:<p><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlop.html">the perlop manpage</a> for details on the operators.</p>
html/pod/perlreref.html:355:<p><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html">the perlfunc manpage</a> for details on the functions.</p>
html/pod/perlreref.html:358:<p><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfaq6.html">the perlfaq6 manpage</a> for FAQs on regular expressions.</p>
html/pod/perlreref.html:361:<p><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrebackslash.html">the perlrebackslash manpage</a> for a reference on backslash sequences.</p>
html/pod/perlreref.html:364:<p><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrecharclass.html">the perlrecharclass manpage</a> for a reference on character classes.</p>
html/pod/perlreref.html:367:<p>The <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/lib/re.html">the re manpage</a> module to alter behaviour and aid
html/pod/perlreref.html:371:<p><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perldebug.html#debugging_regular_expressions">Debugging regular expressions in the perldebug manpage</a></p>
html/pod/perlreref.html:374:<p><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perluniintro.html">the perluniintro manpage</a>, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlunicode.html">the perlunicode manpage</a>, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/lib/charnames.html">the charnames manpage</a> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perllocale.html">the perllocale manpage</a>
html/pod/perlretut.html:96:reference page on regular expressions <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlre.html">the perlre manpage</a>.  Regular expressions
html/pod/perlretut.html:97:are an integral part of the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlop.html#m_"><code>m//</code></a>, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlop.html#s_"><code>s///</code></a>, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlop.html#qr_"><code>qr//</code></a> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#split"><code>split</code></a>
html/pod/perlretut.html:99:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlop.html#regexp_quote_like_operators">Regexp Quote-Like Operators in the perlop manpage</a> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#split">split in the perlfunc manpage</a>.</p>
html/pod/perlretut.html:178:<p>If you're matching against the special default variable <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>$_</code></a>, the
html/pod/perlretut.html:179:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>$_ =~</code></a> part can be omitted:</p>
html/pod/perlretut.html:189:to arbitrary delimiters by putting an <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#m"><code>'m'</code></a> out front:</p>
html/pod/perlretut.html:195:<p><code>/World/</code>, <code>m!World!</code>, and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#m"><code>m{World}</code></a> all represent the
html/pod/perlretut.html:247:represented by <em>escape sequences</em>.  Common examples are <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#t"><code>\t</code></a> for a
html/pod/perlretut.html:248:tab, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#n"><code>\n</code></a> for a newline, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#r"><code>\r</code></a> for a carriage return and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#a"><code>\a</code></a> for a
html/pod/perlretut.html:300:line if the regexp matches the line.  In this line, both <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#print"><code>print</code></a> and
html/pod/perlretut.html:301:<code>/$regexp/</code> use the default variable <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>$_</code></a> implicitly.</p>
html/pod/perlretut.html:363:<p>In the last statement, even though <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#c"><code>'c'</code></a> is the first character in
html/pod/perlretut.html:364:the class, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#a"><code>'a'</code></a> matches because the first character position in the
html/pod/perlretut.html:392:<p>The last two are a little tricky.  In <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#x"><code>[\$x]</code></a>, the backslash protects
html/pod/perlretut.html:393:the dollar sign, so the character class has two members <code>$</code> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#x"><code>x</code></a>.
html/pod/perlretut.html:394:In <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#x"><code>[\\$x]</code></a>, the backslash is protected, so <code>$x</code> is treated as a
html/pod/perlretut.html:445:<p>The period '.' matches any character but &quot;\n&quot; (unless the modifier <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#s"><code>//s</code></a> is
html/pod/perlretut.html:460:as an ordinary period. Because, for example, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#d"><code>\d</code></a> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#w"><code>\w</code></a> are sets
html/pod/perlretut.html:462:fact <code>[^\d\w]</code> is the same as <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#w"><code>[^\w]</code></a>, which is the same as
html/pod/perlretut.html:463:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#w"><code>[\W]</code></a>. Think DeMorgan's laws.</p>
html/pod/perlretut.html:465:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#b"><code>\b</code></a>.  This matches a boundary between a word character and a non-word
html/pod/perlretut.html:475:<p>You might wonder why <code>'.'</code> matches everything but <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#n"><code>&quot;\n&quot;</code></a> - why not
html/pod/perlretut.html:478:while the string <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#n"><code>&quot;\n&quot;</code></a> represents one line, we would like to think
html/pod/perlretut.html:495:by using the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#s"><code>//s</code></a> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#m"><code>//m</code></a> modifiers.  <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#s"><code>//s</code></a> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#m"><code>//m</code></a> stand for
html/pod/perlretut.html:504:except <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#n"><code>&quot;\n&quot;</code></a>.  <code>^</code> matches only at the beginning of the string and
html/pod/perlretut.html:509:any character, even <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#n"><code>&quot;\n&quot;</code></a>.  <code>^</code> matches only at the beginning of
html/pod/perlretut.html:515:matches any character except <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#n"><code>&quot;\n&quot;</code></a>.  <code>^</code> and <code>$</code> are able to match
html/pod/perlretut.html:521:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#n"><code>&quot;\n&quot;</code></a>.  <code>^</code> and <code>$</code>, however, are able to match at the start or end
html/pod/perlretut.html:525:<p>Here are examples of <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#s"><code>//s</code></a> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#m"><code>//m</code></a> in action:</p>
html/pod/perlretut.html:538:<p>Most of the time, the default behavior is what is wanted, but <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#s"><code>//s</code></a> and
html/pod/perlretut.html:539:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#m"><code>//m</code></a> are occasionally very useful.  If <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#m"><code>//m</code></a> is being used, the start
html/pod/perlretut.html:540:of the string can still be matched with <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#a"><code>\A</code></a> and the end of the string
html/pod/perlretut.html:730:<p>For convenience, Perl sets <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>$+</code></a> to the string held by the highest numbered
html/pod/perlretut.html:731:<code>$1</code>, <code>$2</code>,... that got assigned (and, somewhat related, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__n"><code>$^N</code></a> to the
html/pod/perlretut.html:790:backfired -- the subexpression <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#w"><code>(\w+)</code></a> has snatched number 1 and
html/pod/perlretut.html:804:capture buffer is accessible through the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>%+</code></a> hash.</p>
html/pod/perlretut.html:819:<p>If any of the alternatives matches, the hash <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>%+</code></a> is bound to contain the
html/pod/perlretut.html:848:positions of what was matched as contents of the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>@-</code></a> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>@+</code></a>
html/pod/perlretut.html:866:will set <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>$`</code></a> to the part of the string before the match, will set <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>$&amp;</code></a>
html/pod/perlretut.html:867:to the part of the string that matched, and will set <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>$'</code></a> to the part
html/pod/perlretut.html:873:<p>In the second match, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>$`</code></a> equals <code>''</code> because the regexp matched at the
html/pod/perlretut.html:875:second 'the'.  It is important to note that using <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>$`</code></a> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>$'</code></a>
html/pod/perlretut.html:876:slows down regexp matching quite a bit, while <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>$&amp;</code></a> slows it down to a
html/pod/perlretut.html:880:If you need to extract the corresponding substrings, use <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>@-</code></a> and
html/pod/perlretut.html:881:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>@+</code></a> instead:</p>
html/pod/perlretut.html:931:<p><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#a"><code>a?</code></a> means: match 'a' 1 or 0 times</p>
html/pod/perlretut.html:934:<p><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#a"><code>a*</code></a> means: match 'a' 0 or more times, i.e., any number of times</p>
html/pod/perlretut.html:937:<p><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#a"><code>a+</code></a> means: match 'a' 1 or more times, i.e., at least once</p>
html/pod/perlretut.html:940:<p><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#a"><code>a{n,m}</code></a> means: match at least <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#n"><code>n</code></a> times, but not more than <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#m"><code>m</code></a>
html/pod/perlretut.html:944:<p><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#a"><code>a{n,}</code></a> means: match at least <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#n"><code>n</code></a> or more times</p>
html/pod/perlretut.html:947:<p><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#a"><code>a{n}</code></a> means: match exactly <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#n"><code>n</code></a> times</p>
html/pod/perlretut.html:971:with <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#a"><code>/a?.../</code></a>, Perl will first try to match the regexp with the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#a"><code>a</code></a>
html/pod/perlretut.html:973:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#a"><code>a</code></a> present.  For the quantifier <code>*</code>, we get the following:</p>
html/pod/perlretut.html:1037:<p>This regexp matches at the earliest string position, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#t"><code>'T'</code></a>.  One
html/pod/perlretut.html:1039:matched, but <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#r"><code>r</code></a> produces the longest string in the first quantifier.</p>
html/pod/perlretut.html:1044:<p>Here, The earliest possible match is at the first <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#m"><code>'m'</code></a> in
html/pod/perlretut.html:1045:<code>programming</code>. <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#m"><code>m{1,2}</code></a> is the first quantifier, so it gets to match
html/pod/perlretut.html:1053:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#m"><code>'m'</code></a> for the second quantifier <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#m"><code>m{1,2}</code></a>.</p>
html/pod/perlretut.html:1060:position in the string, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#a"><code>'a'</code></a> in <code>programming</code>, leaving <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#m"><code>m{1,2}</code></a>
html/pod/perlretut.html:1061:the opportunity to match both <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#m"><code>m</code></a>'s. Finally,</p>
html/pod/perlretut.html:1064:<p>because it can match zero copies of <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#x"><code>'X'</code></a> at the beginning of the
html/pod/perlretut.html:1065:string.  If you definitely want to match at least one <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#x"><code>'X'</code></a>, use
html/pod/perlretut.html:1066:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#x"><code>X+</code></a>, not <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#x"><code>X*</code></a>.</p>
html/pod/perlretut.html:1075:<p><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#a"><code>a??</code></a> means: match 'a' 0 or 1 times. Try 0 first, then 1.</p>
html/pod/perlretut.html:1078:<p><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#a"><code>a*?</code></a> means: match 'a' 0 or more times, i.e., any number of times,
html/pod/perlretut.html:1082:<p><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#a"><code>a+?</code></a> means: match 'a' 1 or more times, i.e., at least once, but
html/pod/perlretut.html:1086:<p><code>a{n,m}?</code> means: match at least <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#n"><code>n</code></a> times, not more than <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#m"><code>m</code></a>
html/pod/perlretut.html:1090:<p><code>a{n,}?</code> means: match at least <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#n"><code>n</code></a> times, but as few times as
html/pod/perlretut.html:1094:<p><code>a{n}?</code> means: match exactly <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#n"><code>n</code></a> times.  Because we match exactly
html/pod/perlretut.html:1095:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#n"><code>n</code></a> times, <code>a{n}?</code> is equivalent to <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#a"><code>a{n}</code></a> and is just there for
html/pod/perlretut.html:1115:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#m"><code>'m'</code></a> in <code>programming</code>. At this position, the minimal <code>m{1,2}?</code>
html/pod/perlretut.html:1116:matches just one <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#m"><code>'m'</code></a>.  Although the second quantifier <code>.*?</code> would
html/pod/perlretut.html:1129:the first quantifier has to match everything up to the first <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#m"><code>m</code></a>.  The
html/pod/perlretut.html:1130:second minimal quantifier matches just one <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#m"><code>m</code></a> and the third
html/pod/perlretut.html:1138:earliest at position <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#a"><code>'a'</code></a>, so it does.  The second quantifier is
html/pod/perlretut.html:1197:and <code>*</code>: one repetition with <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#b"><code>b+</code></a> of length n, two repetitions with
html/pod/perlretut.html:1198:the first <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#b"><code>b+</code></a> length k and the second with length n-k, m repetitions
html/pod/perlretut.html:1228:<p><code>a{n,m}+</code> means: match at least <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#n"><code>n</code></a> times, not more than <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#m"><code>m</code></a> times,
html/pod/perlretut.html:1229:as many times as possible, and don't give anything up. <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#a"><code>a?+</code></a> is short
html/pod/perlretut.html:1233:<p><code>a{n,}+</code> means: match at least <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#n"><code>n</code></a> times, but as many times as possible,
html/pod/perlretut.html:1234:and don't give anything up. <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#a"><code>a*+</code></a> is short for <code>a{0,}+</code> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#a"><code>a++</code></a> is
html/pod/perlretut.html:1238:<p><code>a{n}+</code> means: match exactly <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#n"><code>n</code></a> times.  It is just there for
html/pod/perlretut.html:1267:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#d"><code>\d+</code></a> and the sign can be matched with <code>[+-]</code>.  Thus the integer
html/pod/perlretut.html:1290:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#d"><code>'\d+\.'</code></a>.  If <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#d"><code>'\d+\.'</code></a> were first, the regexp would happily match that
html/pod/perlretut.html:1300:<p>The exponent is an <code>e</code> or <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#e"><code>E</code></a>, followed by an integer.  So the
html/pod/perlretut.html:1308:decipher.  In complex situations like this, the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#x"><code>//x</code></a> modifier for a
html/pod/perlretut.html:1341:alternation.  Alternatives 1, 2, and 4 all start with <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#d"><code>\d+</code></a>, so it
html/pod/perlretut.html:1389:single line <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#s"><code>//s</code></a>, multi-line <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#m"><code>//m</code></a>, case-insensitive <code>//i</code> and
html/pod/perlretut.html:1390:extended <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#x"><code>//x</code></a> modifiers.  There are a few more things you might
html/pod/perlretut.html:1405:changing over the lifetime of the script, we can add the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#o"><code>//o</code></a>
html/pod/perlretut.html:1420:special delimiter <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#m"><code>m''</code></a>:</p>
html/pod/perlretut.html:1426:<p>Similar to strings, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#m"><code>m''</code></a> acts like apostrophes on a regexp; all other
html/pod/perlretut.html:1427:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#m"><code>m</code></a> delimiters act like quotes.  If the regexp evaluates to the empty string,
html/pod/perlretut.html:1435:<p>The final two modifiers <code>//g</code> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#c"><code>//c</code></a> concern multiple matches.
html/pod/perlretut.html:1441:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#pos"><code>pos()</code></a> function.</p>

html/pod/perlretut.html:1466:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#c"><code>//c</code></a>, as in <code>/regexp/gc</code>.  The current position in the string is
html/pod/perlretut.html:1540:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlop.html#s_"><code>s///</code></a> operator.  The general form is

html/pod/perlretut.html:1547:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlop.html#s_"><code>s///</code></a> returns the number of substitutions made, otherwise it returns

html/pod/perlretut.html:1562:string with just what was quoted.  With the global modifier, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlop.html#s_"><code>s///g</code></a>
html/pod/perlretut.html:1584:    % simple_replace regexp regex <a href="//C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlretut.html">perlretut</a>.pod</pre>
html/pod/perlretut.html:1585:<p>In <code>simple_replace</code> we used the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlop.html#s_"><code>s///g</code></a> modifier to replace all

html/pod/perlretut.html:1590:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlop.html#s_"><code>s///e</code></a> evaluation modifier.  <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlop.html#s_"><code>s///e</code></a> wraps an <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#eval"><code>eval{...}</code></a> around

html/pod/perlretut.html:1800:<p><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#x"><code>\X</code></a> is an abbreviation for a character class that comprises

html/pod/perlretut.html:1814:<code>ascii</code>, <code>cntrl</code>, <code>digit</code>, <code>graph</code>, <code>lower</code>, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#print"><code>print</code></a>, <code>punct</code>,

html/pod/perlretut.html:1820:require using <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#utf8"><code>utf8</code></a>.  The <code>[:digit:]</code>, <code>[:word:]</code>, and

html/pod/perlretut.html:1825:be used just like <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#d"><code>\d</code></a>, with the exception that POSIX character
html/pod/perlretut.html:1839:<p>In Part 1 we discussed the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#o"><code>//o</code></a> modifier, which compiles a regexp
html/pod/perlretut.html:1842:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlop.html#qr_"><code>qr//</code></a> does exactly that: <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlop.html#qr_"><code>qr/string/</code></a> compiles the <code>string</code> as a
html/pod/perlretut.html:1949:operation <a&nbsp;href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#b"><code>$kwds&nbsp;=~&nbsp;/\b($command\w*)/g</code></a> does several things at the
html/pod/perlretut.html:1951:begins (<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#b"><code>\b</code></a>). It tolerates abbreviations due to the added <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#w"><code>\w*</code></a>. It
html/pod/perlretut.html:1961:matching constructs <code>??</code>, <code>*?</code>, <code>+?</code>, <code>{n,m}?</code>, and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#n"><code>{n,}?</code></a>.  The
html/pod/perlretut.html:1971:freeform commenting that is allowed with the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#x"><code>//x</code></a> modifier.</p>
html/pod/perlretut.html:1972:<p>The modifiers <code>//i</code>, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#m"><code>//m</code></a>, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#s"><code>//s</code></a>, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#x"><code>//x</code></a> and <code>//k</code> (or any

html/pod/perlretut.html:2022:word boundary anchor <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#b"><code>\b</code></a> matches wherever a character matching <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#w"><code>\w</code></a>
html/pod/perlretut.html:2035:characters after.  <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlguts.html#b"><code>\b</code></a> looks both ahead and behind, to see if the
html/pod/perlretut.html:2071:Using <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#s"><code>/\s+/</code></a> alone won't work, because spaces are not required between
html/pod/perlretut.html:2094:subexpression <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#a"><code>a*</code></a> first grabbed the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#a"><code>a</code></a>.  Doing so, however,
html/pod/perlretut.html:2095:wouldn't allow the whole regexp to match, so after backtracking, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#a"><code>a*</code></a>
html/pod/perlretut.html:2096:eventually gave back the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#a"><code>a</code></a> and matched the empty string.  Here, what
html/pod/perlretut.html:2097:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#a"><code>a*</code></a> matched was <em>dependent</em> on what the rest of the regexp matched.</p>
html/pod/perlretut.html:2101:<p>The independent subexpression <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#a"><code>(?&gt;a*)</code></a> doesn't care about the rest
html/pod/perlretut.html:2102:of the regexp, so it sees an <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#a"><code>a</code></a> and grabs it.  Then the rest of the
html/pod/perlretut.html:2103:regexp <code>ab</code> cannot match.  Because <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#a"><code>(?&gt;a*)</code></a> is independent, there
html/pod/perlretut.html:2105:up its <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#a"><code>a</code></a>.  Thus the match of the regexp as a whole fails.  A similar
html/pod/perlretut.html:2232:<p>Adding <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#w"><code>\W*</code></a> at either end to eliminate was is to be ignored, we already
html/pod/perlretut.html:2261:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__r"><code>$^R</code></a>.  The variable <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__r"><code>$^R</code></a> can then be used in code expressions later
html/pod/perlretut.html:2307:localized using <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#local"><code>local</code></a>, the changes in the variables produced by the
html/pod/perlretut.html:2341:<p>The result <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__r"><code>$^R</code></a> is automatically localized, so that it will behave
html/pod/perlretut.html:2387:search for <a&nbsp;href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#system"><code>system('rm&nbsp;-rf&nbsp;*');</code></a> to erase your files.  In this
html/pod/perlretut.html:2424:<p>Remember that <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__n"><code>$^N</code></a> is set to whatever was matched by the last
html/pod/perlretut.html:2434:<p>The regexp without the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#x"><code>//x</code></a> modifier is</p>
html/pod/perlretut.html:2448:referred to <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlre.html#special_backtracking_control_verbs">Special Backtracking Control Verbs in the perlre manpage</a> for a
html/pod/perlretut.html:2491:performing some other processing.  Both <code>taint</code> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#eval"><code>eval</code></a> pragmas
html/pod/perlretut.html:2544:starred object, in this case <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#a"><code>'a'</code></a>, and if it matches, goto line 4,
html/pod/perlretut.html:2567:<p>Each step is of the form <code>n&nbsp;&lt;x&gt;&nbsp;&lt;y&gt;</code>, with <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#x"><code>&lt;x&gt;</code></a> the
html/pod/perlretut.html:2571:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perldebguts.html#debugging_regular_expressions">Debugging regular expressions in the perldebguts manpage</a> for much more detail.</p>
html/pod/perlretut.html:2572:<p>An alternative method of debugging regexps is to embed <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#print"><code>print</code></a>
html/pod/perlretut.html:2609:expressions, see the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlre.html">the perlre manpage</a> regular expressions reference page.</p>
html/pod/perlretut.html:2610:<p>For more information on the matching <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlop.html#m_"><code>m//</code></a> and substitution <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlop.html#s_"><code>s///</code></a>
html/pod/perlretut.html:2611:operators, see <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlop.html#regexp_quote_like_operators">Regexp Quote-Like Operators in the perlop manpage</a>.  For

html/pod/perlrun.html:67:is also possible--see <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perldebug.html">the perldebug manpage</a> for details on how to do that.)
html/pod/perlrun.html:135:runs off the end without hitting an <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#exit"><code>exit()</code></a> or <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#die"><code>die()</code></a> operator, an implicit
html/pod/perlrun.html:136:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#exit"><code>exit(0)</code></a> is provided to indicate successful completion.</p>

html/pod/perlsub.html:277:<p>The <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#my"><code>my</code></a> operator declares the listed variables to be lexically

html/pod/perlsub.html:284:with <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#local"><code>local</code></a> instead.</p>
html/pod/perlsub.html:285:<p>Unlike dynamic variables created by the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#local"><code>local</code></a> operator, lexical

html/pod/perlsub.html:300:the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#eval"><code>eval()</code></a> itself.  See <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlref.html">the perlref manpage</a>.</p>

html/pod/perlsub.html:552:<p>Because <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#local"><code>local</code></a> is a run-time operator, it gets executed each time
html/pod/perlsub.html:557:<h3><a name="grammatical_note_on_local__">Grammatical note on <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#local"><code>local()</code></a></a></h3>
html/pod/perlsub.html:558:<p>A <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#local"><code>local</code></a> is simply a modifier on an lvalue expression.  When you assign to
html/pod/perlsub.html:559:a <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#local"><code>local</code></a>ized variable, the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#local"><code>local</code></a> doesn't change whether its list is viewed
html/pod/perlsub.html:598:See <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perl58delta.html#localising_tied_arrays_and_hashes_is_broken">Localising Tied Arrays and Hashes Is Broken in the perl58delta manpage</a> for more
html/pod/perlsub.html:610:those variables is locally lost.  In other words, saying <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#local"><code>local */</code></a>
html/pod/perlsub.html:615:carrying a magic value, you should use <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#local"><code>local *_</code></a> instead of <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#local"><code>local $_</code></a>.
html/pod/perlsub.html:616:As of perl 5.9.1, you can also use the lexical form of <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>$_</code></a> (declaring it
html/pod/perlsub.html:617:with <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#my"><code>my $_</code></a>), which avoids completely this problem.</p>
html/pod/perlsub.html:622:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#local"><code>local</code></a>ize a member of a composite type (i.e. an array or hash element).
html/pod/perlsub.html:623:In this case, the element is <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#local"><code>local</code></a>ized <em>by name</em>. This means that
html/pod/perlsub.html:624:when the scope of the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#local"><code>local()</code></a> ends, the saved value will be
html/pod/perlsub.html:625:restored to the hash element whose key was named in the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#local"><code>local()</code></a>, or
html/pod/perlsub.html:626:the array element whose index was named in the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#local"><code>local()</code></a>.  If that
html/pod/perlsub.html:627:element was deleted while the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#local"><code>local()</code></a> was in effect (e.g. by a
html/pod/perlsub.html:628:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#delete"><code>delete()</code></a> from a hash or a <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#shift"><code>shift()</code></a> of an array), it will spring
html/pod/perlsub.html:630:skipped elements with <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#undef"><code>undef</code></a>.  For instance, if you say</p>
html/pod/perlsub.html:656:<p>The behavior of <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#local"><code>local()</code></a> on non-existent members of composite
html/pod/perlsub.html:761:the equivalent reference mechanism) to <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#push"><code>push</code></a>, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#pop"><code>pop</code></a>, or change the size of
html/pod/perlsub.html:767:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perldata.html#typeglobs_and_filehandles">Typeglobs and Filehandles in the perldata manpage</a>.</p>
html/pod/perlsub.html:770:<h2><a name="when_to_still_use_local__">When to Still Use <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#local"><code>local()</code></a></a></h2>
html/pod/perlsub.html:771:<p>Despite the existence of <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#my"><code>my</code></a>, there are still three places where the
html/pod/perlsub.html:772:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#local"><code>local</code></a> operator still shines.  In fact, in these three places, you

html/pod/perlsub.html:777:<p>The global variables, like <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#_argv"><code>@ARGV</code></a> or the punctuation variables, must be

html/pod/perlsub.html:838:do that, you need to understand references as detailed in <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlref.html">the perlref manpage</a>.
html/pod/perlsub.html:841:to a function and have it <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#pop"><code>pop</code></a> all of then, returning a new list

html/pod/perlsub.html:1219:subversive) behavior for the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#glob"><code>glob</code></a> operator for <em>every</em> namespace,

html/pod/perlsub.html:1237:prototype (such as <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#system"><code>system</code></a> or <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#chomp"><code>chomp</code></a>).  If you override them you won't
html/pod/perlsub.html:1239:<p>The built-ins <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#do"><code>do</code></a>, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#require"><code>require</code></a> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#glob"><code>glob</code></a> can also be overridden, but due
html/pod/perlsub.html:1242:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#do"><code>do BLOCK</code></a> syntax, though).</p>
html/pod/perlsub.html:1243:<p><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#require"><code>require</code></a> has special additional dark magic: if you invoke your
html/pod/perlsub.html:1244:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#require"><code>require</code></a> replacement as <code>require Foo::Bar</code>, it will actually receive
html/pod/perlsub.html:1245:the argument <code>&quot;Foo/Bar.pm&quot;</code> in @_.  See <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#require">require in the perlfunc manpage</a>.</p>
html/pod/perlsub.html:1247:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#glob"><code>glob</code></a>, the <code>&lt;*&gt;</code> glob operator is overridden as well.</p>
html/pod/perlsub.html:1248:<p>In a similar fashion, overriding the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#readline"><code>readline</code></a> function also overrides
html/pod/perlsub.html:1250:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#readpipe"><code>readpipe</code></a> also overrides the operators <code>``</code> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlop.html#qx_"><code>qx//</code></a>.</p>
html/pod/perlsub.html:1251:<p>Finally, some built-ins (e.g. <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#exists"><code>exists</code></a> or <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#grep"><code>grep</code></a>) can't be overridden.</p>
html/pod/perlsub.html:1267:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#import"><code>import</code></a> or <code>unimport</code> method is just skipped instead.)</p>
html/pod/perlsub.html:1269:subroutine using <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#eval"><code>eval()</code></a>, then execute that subroutine using a special
html/pod/perlsub.html:1270:form of <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#goto"><code>goto()</code></a> that erases the stack frame of the <code>AUTOLOAD</code> routine
html/pod/perlsub.html:1272:in <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/lib/AutoLoader.html">the AutoLoader manpage</a>, for example.)  But an <code>AUTOLOAD</code> routine can
html/pod/perlsub.html:1275:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#system"><code>system</code></a> with those arguments.  All you'd do is:</p>
html/pod/perlsub.html:1296:described in <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/lib/AutoLoader.html">the AutoLoader manpage</a> and in <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/lib/AutoSplit.html">the AutoSplit manpage</a>, the standard
