html/pod/perlsyn.html:297:conditional again.  The <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#continue"><code>continue</code></a> block, if any, is <em>not</em> executed.

html/pod/perlsyn.html:723:<p>Although not for the faint of heart, Perl does support a <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#goto"><code>goto</code></a>
html/pod/perlsyn.html:724:statement.  There are three forms: <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#goto"><code>goto</code></a>-LABEL, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#goto"><code>goto</code></a>-EXPR, and
html/pod/perlsyn.html:725:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#goto"><code>goto</code></a>-&amp;NAME.  A loop's LABEL is not actually a valid target for
html/pod/perlsyn.html:726:a <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#goto"><code>goto</code></a>; it's just the name of the loop.</p>
html/pod/perlsyn.html:727:<p>The <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#goto"><code>goto</code></a>-LABEL form finds the statement labeled with LABEL and resumes
html/pod/perlsyn.html:733:construct such as <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#last"><code>last</code></a> or <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#die"><code>die</code></a>.  The author of Perl has never felt the
html/pod/perlsyn.html:734:need to use this form of <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#goto"><code>goto</code></a> (in Perl, that is--C is another matter).</p>
html/pod/perlsyn.html:735:<p>The <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#goto"><code>goto</code></a>-EXPR form expects a label name, whose scope will be resolved
html/pod/perlsyn.html:736:dynamically.  This allows for computed <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#goto"><code>goto</code></a>s per FORTRAN, but isn't
html/pod/perlsyn.html:740:<p>The <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#goto"><code>goto</code></a>-&amp;NAME form is highly magical, and substitutes a call to the
html/pod/perlsyn.html:744:(except that any modifications to <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#__"><code>@_</code></a> in the current subroutine are
html/pod/perlsyn.html:745:propagated to the other subroutine.)  After the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#goto"><code>goto</code></a>, not even <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#caller"><code>caller()</code></a>
html/pod/perlsyn.html:748:structured control flow mechanisms of <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#next"><code>next</code></a>, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#last"><code>last</code></a>, or <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#redo"><code>redo</code></a> instead of
html/pod/perlsyn.html:749:resorting to a <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#goto"><code>goto</code></a>.  For certain applications, the catch and throw pair of
html/pod/perlsyn.html:750:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#eval"><code>eval{}</code></a> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#die"><code>die()</code></a> for exception processing can also be a prudent approach.</p>
html/pod/perlsyn.html:761:text is described in <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlpod.html">the perlpod manpage</a>.</p>
html/pod/perlsyn.html:788:<p>You probably shouldn't rely upon the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#warn"><code>warn()</code></a> being podded out forever.
html/pod/perlsyn.html:799:with <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#eval"><code>eval()</code></a>).  The syntax for this mechanism is the same as for most
html/pod/perlthrtut.html:58:		<li><a href="#controlling_access__lock__">Controlling access: <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#lock"><code>lock()</code></a></a></li>
html/pod/perlthrtut.html:113:uses the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/lib/threads.html">the threads manpage</a> class.</p>
html/pod/perlthrtut.html:125:<p>The <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/lib/threads.html">the threads manpage</a> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/lib/threads/shared.html">the threads::shared manpage</a> modules are included in the core Perl
html/pod/perlthrtut.html:215:system blocks the entire process on <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#sleep"><code>sleep()</code></a>, Perl usually will, as well.</p>
html/pod/perlthrtut.html:247:<p>The <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/lib/threads.html">the threads manpage</a> module provides the basic functions you need to write
html/pod/perlthrtut.html:250:that, we'll go over some of the features of the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/lib/threads.html">the threads manpage</a> module that
html/pod/perlthrtut.html:296:<p>The <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/lib/threads.html">the threads manpage</a> module provides the tools you need to create new
html/pod/perlthrtut.html:339:use the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#join"><code>join()</code></a> method:</p>
html/pod/perlthrtut.html:349:<p>In the example above, the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#join"><code>join()</code></a> method returns as soon as the thread
html/pod/perlthrtut.html:351:any values that the thread might have returned, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#join"><code>join()</code></a> also performs
html/pod/perlthrtut.html:358:that the thread creation call be made in list context (i.e., <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#my"><code>my ($thr)</code></a>).
html/pod/perlthrtut.html:359:See <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/lib/threads/_thr_.html">$thr- in the threads manpage</a>join()&quot;&gt; and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/lib/threads/thread_context.html">THREAD CONTEXT in the threads manpage</a> for more
html/pod/perlthrtut.html:364:<p><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#join"><code>join()</code></a> does three things: it waits for a thread to exit, cleans up
html/pod/perlthrtut.html:409:threads.  <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#die"><code>die()</code></a> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#exit"><code>exit()</code></a> have this property,
html/pod/perlthrtut.html:449:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/lib/threads/shared.html">the threads::shared manpage</a> module and the <code>:shared</code> attribute:</p>
html/pod/perlthrtut.html:505:<p>What do you think <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#_a"><code>$a</code></a> will be? The answer, unfortunately, is <em>it
html/pod/perlthrtut.html:506:depends</em>. Both <code>sub1()</code> and <code>sub2()</code> access the global variable <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#_a"><code>$a</code></a>, once
html/pod/perlthrtut.html:509:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#_a"><code>$a</code></a> can be 2 or 3.</p>
html/pod/perlthrtut.html:524:<p>Two threads both access <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#_a"><code>$a</code></a>.  Each thread can potentially be interrupted
html/pod/perlthrtut.html:525:at any point, or be executed in any order.  At the end, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#_a"><code>$a</code></a> could be 3
html/pod/perlthrtut.html:526:or 4, and both <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#_b"><code>$b</code></a> and <code>$c</code> could be 2 or 3.</p>
html/pod/perlthrtut.html:527:<p>Even <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#_a"><code>$a += 5</code></a> or <code>$a++</code> are not guaranteed to be atomic.</p>
html/pod/perlthrtut.html:545:<h2><a name="controlling_access__lock__">Controlling access: <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#lock"><code>lock()</code></a></a></h2>
html/pod/perlthrtut.html:546:<p>The <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#lock"><code>lock()</code></a> function takes a shared variable and puts a lock on it.
html/pod/perlthrtut.html:550:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#lock"><code>lock()</code></a> function.  Using <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#lock"><code>lock()</code></a> is straightforward: This example has
html/pod/perlthrtut.html:578:<p><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#lock"><code>lock()</code></a> blocks the thread until the variable being locked is
html/pod/perlthrtut.html:579:available.  When <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#lock"><code>lock()</code></a> returns, your thread can be sure that no other
html/pod/perlthrtut.html:585:locking that <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#flock"><code>flock()</code></a> gives you.</p>
html/pod/perlthrtut.html:591:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#lock"><code>lock()</code></a> on the variable goes out of scope. For example:</p>
html/pod/perlthrtut.html:649:<p>The first thread will grab a lock on <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#_a"><code>$a</code></a>, then, after a pause during which
html/pod/perlthrtut.html:651:lock on <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#_b"><code>$b</code></a>.  Meanwhile, the second thread grabs a lock on <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#_b"><code>$b</code></a>, then later
html/pod/perlthrtut.html:652:tries to grab a lock on <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#_a"><code>$a</code></a>.  The second lock attempt for both threads will
html/pod/perlthrtut.html:661:order.  If, for example, you lock variables <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#_a"><code>$a</code></a>, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#_b"><code>$b</code></a>, and <code>$c</code>, always lock
html/pod/perlthrtut.html:662:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#_a"><code>$a</code></a> before <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#_b"><code>$b</code></a>, and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#_b"><code>$b</code></a> before <code>$c</code>.  It's also best to hold on to locks for
html/pod/perlthrtut.html:805:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/lib/threads/shared.html">the threads::shared manpage</a> for more details.</p>
html/pod/perlthrtut.html:955:<p>Finally, once the loop terminates (because we got a 0 or <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#undef"><code>undef</code></a> in the
html/pod/perlthrtut.html:965:done once we return from the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#join"><code>join()</code></a>.</p>
html/pod/perlthrtut.html:981:include most system calls, most I/O, and things like <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#sleep"><code>sleep()</code></a>.</p>
html/pod/perlthrtut.html:995:program.  For example, something as simple as <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#_a"><code>$a = $a + 2</code></a> can behave
html/pod/perlthrtut.html:996:unpredictably with kernel threads if <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#_a"><code>$a</code></a> is visible to other
html/pod/perlthrtut.html:997:threads, as another thread may have changed <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#_a"><code>$a</code></a> between the time it
html/pod/perlthrtut.html:1050:directory using <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#chdir"><code>chdir()</code></a>.  One thread calls <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#chdir"><code>chdir()</code></a>, and the working
html/pod/perlthrtut.html:1052:<p>Even more drastic example of a process-scope change is <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#chroot"><code>chroot()</code></a>:
html/pod/perlthrtut.html:1054:undo it (as opposed to <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#chdir"><code>chdir()</code></a>).</p>
html/pod/perlthrtut.html:1055:<p>Further examples of process-scope changes include <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#umask"><code>umask()</code></a> and
html/pod/perlthrtut.html:1057:<p>Thinking of mixing <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#fork"><code>fork()</code></a> and threads?  Please lie down and wait
html/pod/perlthrtut.html:1058:until the feeling passes.  Be aware that the semantics of <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#fork"><code>fork()</code></a> vary

html/pod/perltie.html:1185:<h2><a name="the_untie_gotcha">The <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#untie"><code>untie</code></a> Gotcha</a></h2>
html/pod/perltie.html:1186:<p>If you intend making use of the object returned from either <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#tie"><code>tie()</code></a> or
html/pod/perltie.html:1187:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#tied"><code>tied()</code></a>, and if the tie's target class defines a destructor, there is a
html/pod/perltie.html:1278:from the tied variable.  When <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#untie"><code>untie()</code></a> is called, that reference is
html/pod/perltie.html:1283:the tied object in $x.  That means that when <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#untie"><code>untie()</code></a> gets called
html/pod/perltie.html:1290:was the good old <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#w"><code>-w</code></a> flag. Which will spot any instances where you call
html/pod/perltie.html:1291:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#untie"><code>untie()</code></a> and there are still valid references to the tied object.  If
html/pod/perltie.html:1293:or was run with the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#w"><code>-w</code></a> flag, Perl prints this
html/pod/perltie.html:1298:there are no valid references to the tied object <em>before</em> <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#untie"><code>untie()</code></a> is
html/pod/perltie.html:1304:class functionality are really associated with <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#untie"><code>untie</code></a> and which with
html/pod/perltie.html:1324:<p>See <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/ext/DB_File/DB_File.html">the DB_File manpage</a> or <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/lib/Config.html">the Config manpage</a> for some interesting <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#tie"><code>tie()</code></a> implementations.
html/pod/perltie.html:1325:A good starting point for many <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#tie"><code>tie()</code></a> implementations is with one of the
html/pod/perltie.html:1326:modules <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/lib/Tie/Scalar.html">the Tie::Scalar manpage</a>, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/lib/Tie/Array.html">the Tie::Array manpage</a>, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/lib/Tie/Hash.html">the Tie::Hash manpage</a>, or <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/lib/Tie/Handle.html">the Tie::Handle manpage</a>.</p>
html/pod/perltie.html:1331:<p>The bucket usage information provided by <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#scalar"><code>scalar(%hash)</code></a> is not
html/pod/perltie.html:1337:<p>Counting the number of entries in a hash via <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#scalar"><code>scalar(keys(%hash))</code></a>
html/pod/perltie.html:1338:or <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#scalar"><code>scalar(values(%hash)</code></a>) is inefficient since it needs to iterate
html/pod/perltie.html:1347:nearest CPAN site as described in <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlmodlib.html">the perlmodlib manpage</a> for source code.  Note
html/pod/perltie.html:1351:<p>Tied filehandles are still incomplete.  <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#sysopen"><code>sysopen()</code></a>, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#truncate"><code>truncate()</code></a>,

html/pod/perltoot.html:1541:wanted to override Perl's idea of <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#gethostbyname"><code>gethostbyname()</code></a> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#gethostbyaddr"><code>gethostbyaddr()</code></a> so

html/pod/perlunicode.html:260:<p>The <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#pack"><code>pack()</code></a>/<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#unpack"><code>unpack()</code></a> letter <code>C</code> does <em>not</em> change, since it is often 
html/pod/perlunicode.html:262:<p>There is a new <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#u"><code>U</code></a> specifier that converts between Unicode characters
html/pod/perlunicode.html:263:and code points. There is also a <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#w"><code>W</code></a> specifier that is the equivalent of
html/pod/perlunicode.html:264:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#chr"><code>chr</code></a>/<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#ord"><code>ord</code></a> and properly handles character values even if they are above 255.</p>
html/pod/perlunicode.html:267:<p>The <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#chr"><code>chr()</code></a> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#ord"><code>ord()</code></a> functions work on characters, similar to
html/pod/perlunicode.html:268:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#pack"><code>pack(&quot;W&quot;)</code></a> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#unpack"><code>unpack(&quot;W&quot;)</code></a>, <em>not</em> <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#pack"><code>pack(&quot;C&quot;)</code></a> and
html/pod/perlunicode.html:269:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#unpack"><code>unpack(&quot;C&quot;)</code></a>.  <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#pack"><code>pack(&quot;C&quot;)</code></a> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#unpack"><code>unpack(&quot;C&quot;)</code></a> are methods for
html/pod/perlunicode.html:270:emulating byte-oriented <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#chr"><code>chr()</code></a> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#ord"><code>ord()</code></a> on Unicode strings.
html/pod/perlunicode.html:286:<p><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#lc"><code>lc()</code></a>, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#uc"><code>uc()</code></a>, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#lcfirst"><code>lcfirst()</code></a>, and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#ucfirst"><code>ucfirst()</code></a> work for the following cases:</p>
html/pod/perlunicode.html:300:<p>But you can also define your own mappings to be used in the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#lc"><code>lc()</code></a>,
html/pod/perlunicode.html:301:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#lcfirst"><code>lcfirst()</code></a>, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#uc"><code>uc()</code></a>, and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#ucfirst"><code>ucfirst()</code></a> (or their string-inlined versions).</p>
html/pod/perlunicode.html:306:<p>And finally, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#reverse"><code>scalar reverse()</code></a> reverses by character rather than by byte.</p>
html/pod/perlunicode.html:313:character classes via the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#p"><code>\p{}</code></a> &quot;matches property&quot; construct and
html/pod/perlunicode.html:314:the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#p"><code>\P{}</code></a> negation, &quot;doesn't match property&quot;.</p>

html/pod/perlunicode.html:918:<p>You can also define your own mappings to be used in the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#lc"><code>lc()</code></a>,

html/pod/perlunicode.html:1205:class <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#w"><code>\w</code></a> will work differently depending on if data is eight-bit bytes

html/pod/perlunifaq.html:293:<h2><a name="what_is_the_difference_between__encoding_and__utf8">What is the difference between <code>:encoding</code> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#utf8"><code>:utf8</code></a>?</a></h2>
html/pod/perlunifaq.html:296:<p>Instead of <code>:encoding(UTF-8)</code>, you can simply use <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#utf8"><code>:utf8</code></a>, which skips the
html/pod/perlunifaq.html:300:byte sequences. Using <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#utf8"><code>:utf8</code></a> for input can sometimes result in security
html/pod/perlunifaq.html:304:the same reason that <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#utf8"><code>:utf8</code></a> can.</p>
html/pod/perlunifaq.html:305:<p>There are some shortcuts for oneliners; see <code>-C</code> in <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html">the perlrun manpage</a>.</p>
html/pod/perlunifaq.html:308:<h2><a name="what_s_the_difference_between_utf_8_and_utf8">What's the difference between <code>UTF-8</code> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#utf8"><code>utf8</code></a>?</a></h2>
html/pod/perlunifaq.html:309:<p><code>UTF-8</code> is the official standard. <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#utf8"><code>utf8</code></a> is Perl's way of being liberal in
html/pod/perlunifaq.html:312:that are too liberal, you may have to use <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#utf8"><code>utf8</code></a>. The full explanation is in
html/pod/perlunifaq.html:313:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/lib/Encode.html">the Encode manpage</a>.</p>
html/pod/perlunifaq.html:319:default; see <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/lib/Encode/handling_malformed_data.html">Handling Malformed Data in the Encode manpage</a> for more ways of dealing with
html/pod/perlunifaq.html:343:<p><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlunicode.html">the perlunicode manpage</a>, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perluniintro.html">the perluniintro manpage</a>, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/lib/Encode.html">the Encode manpage</a></p>
html/pod/perluniintro.html:149:For further information see <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/lib/Unicode/UCD.html">the Unicode::UCD manpage</a>.</p>
html/pod/perluniintro.html:160:<em>surrogates</em> and <em>byte order marks</em> (BOMs) are--see <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlunicode.html">the perlunicode manpage</a>.</p>
html/pod/perluniintro.html:170:necessary.</strong> In earlier releases the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#utf8"><code>utf8</code></a> pragma was used to declare
html/pod/perluniintro.html:178:scripts with legacy 8-bit data in them would break.  See <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/lib/utf8.html">the utf8 manpage</a>.</p>
html/pod/perluniintro.html:206:<p>To output UTF-8, use the <code>:encoding</code> or <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#utf8"><code>:utf8</code></a> output layer.  Prepending</p>
html/pod/perluniintro.html:212:handles, default <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#open"><code>open()</code></a> layer, and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#_argv"><code>@ARGV</code></a> by using either
html/pod/perluniintro.html:213:the <code>-C</code> command line switch or the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#perl_unicode"><code>PERL_UNICODE</code></a> environment
html/pod/perluniintro.html:214:variable, see <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html">the perlrun manpage</a> for the documentation of the <code>-C</code> switch.</p>
html/pod/perluniintro.html:229:remain, see <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlebcdic.html">the perlebcdic manpage</a> for details.</p>
html/pod/perluniintro.html:240:use the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#x"><code>\x{...}</code></a> notation in double-quoted strings:</p>
html/pod/perluniintro.html:246:<p>At run-time you can use <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#chr"><code>chr()</code></a>:</p>
html/pod/perluniintro.html:250:<p>Naturally, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#ord"><code>ord()</code></a> will do the reverse: it turns a character into
html/pod/perluniintro.html:252:<p>Note that <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#x"><code>\x..</code></a> (no <code>{}</code> and only two hexadecimal digits), <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#x"><code>\x{...}</code></a>,
html/pod/perluniintro.html:253:and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#chr"><code>chr(...)</code></a> for arguments less than <code>0x100</code> (decimal 256)
html/pod/perluniintro.html:257:characters regardless of the numeric value, use <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#pack"><code>pack(&quot;U&quot;, ...)</code></a>
html/pod/perluniintro.html:258:instead of <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#x"><code>\x..</code></a>, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#x"><code>\x{...}</code></a>, or <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#chr"><code>chr()</code></a>.</p>
html/pod/perluniintro.html:264:<p>And, as mentioned above, you can also <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#pack"><code>pack()</code></a> numbers into Unicode
html/pod/perluniintro.html:268:<p>Note that both <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#x"><code>\x{...}</code></a> and <code>\N{...}</code> are compile-time string
html/pod/perluniintro.html:270:run-time functionality, use <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#chr"><code>chr()</code></a> and <code>charnames::vianame()</code>.</p>
html/pod/perluniintro.html:282:strings as usual.  Functions like <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#index"><code>index()</code></a>, <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#length"><code>length()</code></a>, and
html/pod/perluniintro.html:283:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlvar.html#substr"><code>substr()</code></a> will work on the Unicode characters; regular expressions
html/pod/perluniintro.html:284:will work on the Unicode characters (see <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlunicode.html">the perlunicode manpage</a> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlretut.html">the perlretut manpage</a>).</p>
html/pod/perluniintro.html:291:have <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#x"><code>\X</code></a> for matching a combining character sequence.</p>
html/pod/perluniintro.html:324:<p>and on already open streams, use <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#binmode"><code>binmode()</code></a>:</p>
html/pod/perluniintro.html:332:many encodings have several aliases.  Note that the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#utf8"><code>:utf8</code></a> layer
html/pod/perluniintro.html:334:the loose matching of encoding names. Also note that <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#utf8"><code>:utf8</code></a> is unsafe for

html/pod/perluniintro.html:352:the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#open"><code>open</code></a> pragma.  See <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/lib/open.html">the open manpage</a>, or look at the following example.</p>
html/pod/perluniintro.html:361:<p>With the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#open"><code>open</code></a> pragma you can use the <code>:locale</code> layer</p>
html/pod/perluniintro.html:375:<p>The <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/lib/open.html">the open manpage</a> pragma affects all the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#open"><code>open()</code></a> calls after the pragma by
html/pod/perluniintro.html:377:streams, use explicit layers directly in the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#open"><code>open()</code></a> call.</p>
html/pod/perluniintro.html:379:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#binmode"><code>binmode()</code></a>; see <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#binmode">binmode in the perlfunc manpage</a>.</p>
html/pod/perluniintro.html:381:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#open"><code>open()</code></a> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#binmode"><code>binmode()</code></a>, only with the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#open"><code>open</code></a> pragma.  The
html/pod/perluniintro.html:382:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlrun.html#utf8"><code>:utf8</code></a> and <code>:encoding(...)</code> methods do work with all of <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#open"><code>open()</code></a>,
html/pod/perluniintro.html:383:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#binmode"><code>binmode()</code></a>, and the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#open"><code>open</code></a> pragma.</p>
html/pod/perluniintro.html:393:<p>The naming of encodings, both by the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#open"><code>open()</code></a> and by the <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#open"><code>open</code></a>
html/pod/perluniintro.html:398:list see <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/lib/Encode/Supported.html">the Encode::Supported manpage</a>.</p>
html/pod/perluniintro.html:399:<p><a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#read"><code>read()</code></a> reads characters and returns the number of characters.
html/pod/perluniintro.html:400:<a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#seek"><code>seek()</code></a> and <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#tell"><code>tell()</code></a> operate on byte counts, as do <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#sysread"><code>sysread()</code></a>

html/pod/perlxs.html:908:<h2><a name="the_length_name__keyword">The <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#length"><code>length(NAME)</code></a> Keyword</a></h2>
html/pod/perlxs.html:910:argument <a href="file://C|\camelbox\html/pod/perlfunc.html#name"><code>NAME</code></a>, one can substitute the name of the length-argument by
